In hopes of catching up to Google's ad revenue, Yahoo will soon release a simpler, more stable and more nuanced search-advertising system.

When Yahoo finally switches on the new search-advertising software code-named Project Panama this summer, users of its search engine will hardly notice a difference. But if Yahoo's project was worth the two years and tens of millions of dollars it cost -- far more money and time than it expected -- users will find the text ads adjacent to the main search results just a little more interesting, luring them to click on those ads a little more often.     Those clicks should immediately turn into a lot more cash for Yahoo. It will not say how much. But Jordan Rohan, an analyst for RBC Capital Markets, estimates that if the strategy works, Yahoo will increase search-advertising revenue at least 20 percent right away -- about $125 million in the fourth quarter of this year and $600 million next year.

The Microsoft-Google rivalry is shaping up as a titanic corporate clash for the ages.     It may not turn out that way. Markets and corporate fortunes routinely defy prediction. INTERNATIONAL   A3-14    Iranian Leader Lectures Bush in Letter on Religion  The president of Iran, in a letter sent to president Bush on Monday, wrote that Western democracy has failed and that the invasion of Iraq, American treatment of prisoners of war and support for Israel could not be reconciled with Christian values.   A1    The United States and its European negotiating partners are preparing to repackage economic incentives aimed at inducing Iran to cooperate in eliminating its suspected nuclear weapons program, American and European officials said.   A14    U.S. Agrees to Aid Palestinians  Yielding to pressure from its allies, the Bush administration endorsed a European proposal to increase aid to the Palestinian territories, including money that could possibly go to pay salaries of civil servants working under Hamas.   A6    Sunnis Forming Civilian Patrols  As evidence mounts that Shiite police commandos are carrying out secret killings, Sunni Arab neighborhoods in Baghdad have begun forming citizen groups to keep the forces out of their areas.   A1    U.N. Votes on Rights Council  The United Nations General Assembly chose members of the new Human Rights Council in an election that admitted some countries with poor rights records but barred notorious violators.   A12    Romanian Orphans Still Abused  Investigators for an advocacy group based in Washington have found that thousands of children in government-run institutions in Romania are living in conditions that are little changed from a decade ago, when systematic abuse and squalor prompted an international outcry and calls for reform.   A3    NATIONAL   A15-22    Bush's Low Ratings Are Grim for Republicans  President Bush's approval rating for his management of foreign policy, Iraq and the economy have fallen to the lowest levels of his presidency, which has created a grim political environment for the White House and Congressional Republicans, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.   A1    Pentagon's Expanding Spy Role  President Bush's selection of Gen. Michael V. Hayden to be the next director of the Central Intelligence Agency sets the stage for new wrangling with the Pentagon, which is rapidly expanding its own global spying and terrorist-tracking operations, which were long considered C.I.A. roles.   A1    Ordeal of Prisoners in Storm  More than 100 teenagers held in detention during Hurricane Katrina endured horrific conditions after the storm according to a new report.   A15    Nominee Courts Senators  As Senate Republicans promised to begin confirmation hearings soon, Gen. Michael V. Hayden spent the day trying to win over lawmakers wary of his nomination to lead the Central Intelligence Agency.   A22    G.O.P. Deal on Tax Plan  Republicans in Congress agreed on a $69 billion bill that would extend President Bush's tax cuts for investors for two years and temporarily block a big jump in the alternative minimum tax, possibly giving the party a much-sought victory.   A15    Newspaper Sale Causes Feud  When David V. Mitchell sold the local newspaper in Point Reyes Station, Calif., to Robert I. Plotkin, no one could have predicted the ensuing public battle, complete with a disputed claim of attempted murder.   A22    NEW YORK/REGION   B1-7    Booker Elected Mayor, Newark Looks to New Era  Cory Booker, the young, Ivy League-educated lawyer who fought an unsuccessful battle four years ago against the domineering incumbent Sharpe James, was elected mayor, marking the start of a new political era in New Jersey's largest city.   A1    Response Questioned  The Civilian Complaint Review Board, the New York City agency investigating the police response to protests at the 2004 Republican National Convention, sharply criticized the performance of two deputy police chiefs, saying that they yelled incomprehensible orders to marchers, which resulted in numerous unnecessary arrests.   B1    McCain Invitation Protested  About three dozen students and professors at New School University, a bastion of liberal politics, rallied to protest the school's decision to invite Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican, to serve as commencement speaker.   B1    Murdoch-Clinton Synergy  Rupert Murdoch, who founded the media empire that includes Fox News and The New York Post, has agreed to throw a fund-raiser this summer for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who is often a prime target of his news outlets.   B1    ARTS   E1-10    More Twists in Detective Case  Anthony Pellicano, the jailed private detective charged with wiretapping and conspiracy in Hollywood's biggest scandal in decades, conspired recently with organized-crime figures to try to assassinate a key witness against him, federal prosecutors say.   E1    BUSINESS DAY   C1-14    C.E.O.'s and Jet Travel  As chief executives' salaries have risen sharply, shareholders are also paying more for their personal travel on corporate jets, new government data show.   A1    Bush's Stance on the Yuan  After three years of pushing China to let its currency float more freely, the Bush administration still appears reluctant to accuse China of manipulating its exchange rate.   C1    Insight Into a Tech Rivalry  The Microsoft-Google rivalry is shaping up as a titanic corporate clash for the ages. A look at similar battles in the past may shed light on who will emerge as the winner in this confrontation. U.S. AND THE YUAN The Bush administration said that although it was ''extremely dissatisfied'' with China's refusal to allow its currency to fluctuate more freely in value, it would not formally cite China as a currency manipulator and provoke a confrontation. [C1.]    FED RAISES RATES The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates again, its 16th increase in two years, and gave itself room to raise them again in June. Its statement illustrated the uncertainty that confronts the Fed and its new chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, above, as policy makers prepare to shift gears after two years of raising rates. [C1.]    TAX CUT BILL The House passed a $69 billion bill to extend President Bush's tax cuts for investors for two more years, giving the White House a victory at a time when its agenda is largely stalled. [C10.]    IMPACT OF CUTS Most of the benefits of the tax cut will flow to high-income Americans. [C1.]    AIRBUS TO REDESIGN PLANE Airbus, facing a growing chorus of doubts from customers, is expected to radically redesign its midsize plane, the A350, in a move that could give Boeing the upper hand in a critical segment of the commercial aircraft market. [C3.]    NEW GOOGLE SERVICES Google introduced several services that draw on contributions from users. [C6.]    ENRON TRIAL DEVELOPMENT The judge in the Enron trial dealt a serious blow to the two former chief executives accused of defrauding investors by agreeing to allow jurors to find both men guilty for consciously avoiding knowing about wrongdoing at the company. [C3.]    NASDAQ'S LONDON STAKE Nasdaq raised its stake in the London Stock Exchange to 24.1 percent. In addition, the insurance company AXA said that it had bought up 10.6 percent of the London exchange. Analysts said AXA probably hoped to sell the shares to Nasdaq at a higher price. [C11.]    STOCKS ARE MOSTLY LOWER The Dow Jones industrial average rose 2.88 points, to 11,642.65. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 2.29 points, to 1,322.85, and the Nasdaq composite index sank 17.51 points, to 2,320.74. [C11.]    THE OPRAH EFFECT IN COSMETICS Oprah Winfrey drives enormous traffic to cosmetics counters, spas and doctors' offices when she endorses a product or a treatment on her show, according to beauty industry executives. Some doctors say that can be a problem when the beauty treatment being featured is medical, with possible complications, rather than simply a cosmetic or spa procedure. [G1.]    CATHOLIC RADIO CHANNEL The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced a deal to work with Sirius Satellite Radio to create a 24/7 Catholic channel. [E1.]    ENTER THE DRAENEI Blizzard Entertainment, the company behind the World of Warcraft game, announced that its latest expansion, called the Burning Crusade, will include the introduction of an otherworldly species called the Draenei. [E3.]    TOYOTA PROFIT SURGES Toyota posted a 17.2 percent jump in net profit, to a record 1.37 trillion yen ($12.1 billion) in the fiscal year that ended March 31. It was its sixth consecutive year of record profit. Toyota also released a sales forecast that analysts said showed it was on track to dethrone General Motors as the world's largest carmaker, possibly as soon as this year. [C4.]    ASIA IN U.S. CAR CAPITAL Detroit is having trouble adjusting to a new reality: the Asian car companies it once vowed to vanquish have moved squarely into its front yard. [A1.]    ACTION ON OIL LEASES Amid a growing uproar over lucrative government incentives for oil and gas producers, the House Appropriations Committee approved a bill that would order the Interior Department to renegotiate about 1,000 leases for drilling in the Gulf of Mexico. THE AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP Inc., the insurance companies, said that its net income fell nearly 16 percent in the quarter. Net income was $3.2 billion, down from $3.8 billion a year earlier. (AP)    NORTHWEST AIRLINES, which filed for bankruptcy in September, reported a first-quarter net loss of $1.1 billion, hurt by reorganization costs and rising fuel prices. Federal District Judge Lewis A. Kaplan said he might consider forcing KPMG to pay legal fees for employees or former employees accused in criminal tax case. (AP)

SENATE APPROVES TAX BILL -- The Senate voted 54 to 44 to pass $70 billion in tax cuts, most of which will flow to the nation's wealthiest taxpayers. The action ensured that virtually all of President Bush's tax cuts will be locked in place until after the next presidential election. [Page A1.]    STOCKS FALL -- Stock prices fell sharply as investors worried that rising oil prices would quicken the pace of inflation and force policy makers to raise interest rates further. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.3 percent, to 1,305.92. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 1.2 percent, to 11,500.73, and the Nasdaq fell 2 percent, to 2,272.70. [C1.]    MARKET REVIVAL IN CHINA -- After sinking to an eight-year low last year and being declared all but dead, the Chinese stock market has recently soared to a level more than 50 percent higher from a year ago. [C9.]    WAL-MART SUPPLIER CONTROVERSY -- Wal-Mart, having helped start an advocacy group that trumpets the company's contributions to America, is quietly helping that organization recruit Wal-Mart's suppliers to join the public relations offensive -- a move that some vendors say puts improper pressure on them. [C1.]    ORGANIC FOOD AND WAL-MART -- Starting this summer, there will be a lot more organic food on supermarket shelves, and it should cost a lot less. The reason is that Wal-Mart wants to sell more organic food -- and because of its size and clout, Wal-Mart usually gets what it wants. [A1]    INHALER SHORTAGE -- A federally mandated shift to a more ozone-friendly version of hand-held inhalers for asthma attacks is creating spot shortages of the devices. [C1.]    MERGER RESISTANCE IN EUROPE -- Few business executives are as determined to forge a single European market as Alessandro Profumo, the Italian banker who took over HVB, the German bank. For other European chief executives eager to expand across borders, Mr. Profumo's experience shows that building a pan-European enterprise requires luck, stamina, and a thick skin. [C1.]    NEW TWIST IN TRADING CASE -- Federal prosecutors arrested Jason C. Smith and charged him with leaking secret information from grand jury proceedings to David Pajcin and Eugene Plotkin, two men previously accused of running an insider-trading ring that reaped $6.7 million in illegal profits in 2004 and 2005. [C1.]    WARNING ON PAXIL -- GlaxoSmithKline has sent letters to doctors warning that its antidepressant drug Paxil appears to increase the risk of suicide attempts in young adults. [A26.]    SUIT OVER AIDS DRUG -- Two patients' rights groups in India sued to stop Gilead Sciences, a California biopharmaceutical company, from patenting the AIDS drug Viread, which is available in India in a generic form. If the drug is patented, it will become too expensive for patients in developing countries, the groups argue. [A4.]    BLACKBERRY IN CHINA -- Research In Motion said it would introduce its BlackBerry wireless service in China. But the announcement prompted questions about how the service would fit into the Chinese government's program of communications surveillance and censorship. [C3.]    HEALTH BILL FAILS -- A small-business health insurance bill collapsed in the Senate as critics contended that the bill would strip away years of consumer protections. [A23.]    PAY-FOR-PLAY SETTLEMENT -- The Universal Music Group has agreed to pay $12 million to settle accusations that executives paid radio programmers to play songs. [C3.]    ONLINE    SHORTS AS OFFICE WEAR -- Dress codes these days are as elastic as a bungee cord, expanding to accommodate all manner of once unthinkable workplace infractions. The third rail in the transportation business is the electrified conduit that supplies power to a railway. Pension reform, so the saying goes, is the third rail of politics: Grab it and you die. The need to adapt state-financed retirement systems to changing demographics is acute, but so are the vested interests at all points on the political spectrum - which is one reason elected governments from Washington to Warsaw have resisted tackling the issue. So the announcement this week that the British government was proposing to overhaul its pension system was an illustration of just how bleak the future of social security systems has become, and how change can no longer be postponed. It also represents a significant political compromise between Prime Minister Tony Blair and his chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, over how to swell the coffers of the British pension system, which has one of the lowest payouts in Europe. That Blair, who faces serious political troubles over Iraq, should now be willing to grab the third rail is not too surprising: As one of the characters in "The West Wing," a television show about the inner workings of a fictional White House, put it, that is where the power is.

Microsoft Sets Sail Against Pirates    Q. This just started about a week ago, but every time we start up we get a message saying, ''This copy of Windows is not genuine'' and ''You may be a victim of software counterfeiting.'' What can I do? Is this a problem that needs to be corrected?    A. The messages are part of Microsoft's continuing efforts to combat the piracy of its software. Those messages, along with notification balloons and desktop banners, may appear on your screen if the company senses through Internet updates that you are not using a licensed copy of its Windows XP operating system.

No fewer than 300 cities and towns around the nation have taken wireless Internet access, or Wi-Fi, to the people. San Francisco's aim is to make the entire city a hot spot, Chicago plans to blanket the city with access, and large parts of Philadelphia are to go wireless soon. But New York, which should be leading the way, is dragging. A plan to offer free Wi-Fi access in city parks has been moving slowly, and a larger vision has yet to take shape.      Wide dissemination of Wi-Fi is not the future. It is now, needed by businesses, educators and especially the underserved populations on the wrong side of the digital divide. Rural communities have known for a while that going wireless is cheaper, more reliable and allows even the most remote areas to log in. It spares the expense of laying down extensive networks of cables, not to mention the work and time involved.

On the banks of the windswept Columbia River, Google is working on a secret weapon in its quest to dominate the next generation of Internet computing. But it is hard to keep a secret when it is a computing center as big as two football fields, with twin cooling plants protruding four stories into the sky.     The complex, sprawling like an information-age factory, heralds a substantial expansion of a worldwide computing network handling billions of search queries a day and a growing repertory of other Internet services.

Q. Can the data on a U.S.B. flash drive be password-protected?

Password Protection For Portable Drives    Q. Can the data on a U.S.B. flash drive be password-protected?    A. Those tiny flash-memory drives that plug into a computer's U.S.B. port are great for hauling large files between computers -- but can cause worry if they get lost while storing sensitive information. Anyone who finds an unprotected portable drive could plug it into a computer and browse the files stored on it.

YOUR digital life spins at 7,200 rotations a minute on your computer's hard drive. A delicate reading arm, hovering a fraction of an inch above the surface of the drive's spinning platters, dances across them at 60 miles an hour; one bump, and your files are toast. Your hard drive's likelihood of mechanical failure is 100 percent; it's just a matter of when.      And this is how society has chosen to preserve its future?

EVER since the first Prius rolled off the assembly line almost a decade ago at the Takaoka plant not far from Toyota City, hybrid cars have basically been a luxury item. If you owned one, you could feel good about using less gasoline and being a trendsetter, but you couldn't expect the fuel savings to make up for the thousands of extra dollars that the hybrid cost. There was no financial reward for environmental virtue.     But in the last few months, something important has changed. Gas prices have settled in at close to $3 a gallon, which is enough to make a few hybrids almost worth it, if not quite. And since the start of the year, the federal government has been giving generous tax credits to hybrid buyers, pushing the Prius and a couple of other hybrids into bargain territory.

Summer camp directors have a new scourge, and it is not mosquitoes or impetigo. It is the Internet, specifically sites like MySpace, Facebook and Friendster, where young people often post personal or revealing information.     Camps say they are increasingly concerned about being identified in photographs or comments on these sites, even innocuously. They worry about online predators tracking children to camp and about their image being tarnished by inappropriate Internet juxtapositions -- a mention, say, of the camp on a site that also has crude language or sexually suggestive pictures.

A Senate committee rejected rules that would bar telephone and cable providers from charging new fees for priority access to their high-speed networks.

A Senate committee rejected on Wednesday rules that would bar telephone and cable providers from charging new fees for priority access to their high-speed networks.     The Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee decided yesterday, in an 11-to-11 vote, against attaching the so-called Net neutrality measure to a bill making it easier for telephone companies to sell television service. A measure must have a majority of votes to pass.

Three major decisions affecting the luxury goods company were handed down this week by French appeals courts. On Wednesday, the company's Louis Vuitton leather-goods unit won an appeal against the search engine Google over online ads for competitors or counterfeiters; the court ruled that Google had engaged in trademark counterfeiting, a decision that the court said would apply to all of the search engine's sites in more than 130 countries. On Thursday, another appeals court ruled that Louis Vuitton's flagship store on the Champs-√âlys√©es in Paris could remain open on Sundays while a lawsuit by unions to force the store to close on "the day of the Lord" moved through the system - a process that could take months. Then on Friday, a Paris appeals court upheld a January 2004 ruling that found the investment bank Morgan Stanley guilty of producing biased analyst research against the luxury group during a 1999-2000 takeover battle with Gucci. Some of these issues are subject to further adjudication. But as any company that has been involved in litigation knows well, you must take your victories where you find them.

Google is a solid member of the Fortune 500 with $9 billion in cash, but it is stubbornly sticking to its do-it-yourself approach to technology.

When Google was a graduate-school project being run from a Silicon Valley garage, its founders, Larry Page and Sergey Brin, built their own computers out of cheap parts meant for personal computers. They wanted to save money, and they felt that they could design a network of computers that would search the Web more efficiently than those available from traditional manufacturers.     Google no longer needs to pinch pennies. It is a solid member of the Fortune 500 with $9 billion in cash. Still, it is stubbornly sticking to its do-it-yourself approach to technology. Even as it spends more than $1.5 billion this year on operations centers and technology, most of the hundreds of thousands of servers it will deploy are being custom-made based on Google's own eccentric designs.

INTERNATIONAL   A3-9    Israel Hits Fatah Offices As Strikes Increase in Gaza  Israeli aircraft intensified their attacks on Palestinian targets in Gaza, hitting the downtown offices of the Fatah political party and sites in the northern part of the territory after Israel's prime minister ordered his military to do whatever necessary to pressure militants to free a captured Israeli soldier. To keep customers from leaving, they are discounting their television and phone plans, throwing in premium movie channels and faster connections to the Internet. A FEW years back, a technology writer named John Battelle began talking about how the Internet had made it possible to predict the future. When people went to the home page of Google or Yahoo and entered a few words into a search engine, what they were really doing, he realized, was announcing their intentions.      They typed in ''Alaskan cruise'' because they were thinking about taking one or ''baby names'' because they were planning on needing one. If somebody were to add up all this information, it would produce a pretty good notion of where the world was headed, of what was about to get hot and what was going out of style.

On its home page, Google Trends offers a number of sample searches. Some of them can be interesting like the recent one showing that "blogs" is now searched more often than "magazines" but I found most of them to be too general. It's much more fun to do your own.     To look at the search history of a single term, simply enter it into the window Google provides and hit return. The data goes back to the beginning of 2004.

India's problems are unlikely to be solved as long as the wealthy, both inside and outside the country, choose to believe their own complacent myths.

''INDIA is a roaring capitalist success story.'' So says the latest issue of Foreign Affairs; and last week many leading business executives and politicians in India celebrated as Lakshmi Mittal, the fifth richest man in the world, finally succeeded in his hostile takeover of the Luxembourgian steel company Arcelor. India's leading business newspaper, The Economic Times, summed up the general euphoria over the event in its regular feature, ''The Global Indian Takeover'': ''For India, it is a harbinger of things to come -- economic superstardom.''     This sounds persuasive as long as you don't know that Mr. Mittal, who lives in Britain, announced his first investment in India only last year. He is as much an Indian success story as Sergey Brin, the Russian-born co-founder of Google, is proof of Russia's imminent economic superstardom.

New York City intends to study whether to establish a citywide broadband network similar to those planned by cities like Philadelphia and San Francisco.

Even as a contractor moves ahead with plans to install wireless networks in 10 parks, New York City intends to study whether to establish a citywide broadband network similar to those planned by cities like Philadelphia and San Francisco.     The study, commissioned by the city's Economic Development Corporation, will examine ''whether there is a need for a citywide broadband network as a municipal initiative'' and what legal, technical, logistical and economic challenges such a project would involve, according to a request for proposals that the city released on June 14.

The Internet auctioneer eBay is facing new concerns over executive turnover and management succession at a time when Google is invading its turf.

Even as many of the other hot Internet companies were faltering in recent years, eBay remained a Wall Street darling. It made two big acquisitions -- PayPal and the Internet phone service Skype -- and continued to post heady sales and earnings growth as it expanded overseas.     But after a trying week in which one of the company's top executives resigned, eBay is facing new concerns over executive turnover and management succession, adding to what may be an even bigger challenge: an invasion of its turf by Google.

Should AOL sacrifice its cash cow in hopes of finding a prosperous future?     In two weeks, the board of Time Warner Inc., which owns AOL, will hear a proposal from Jonathan Miller, AOL's chief executive, calling for a near halt in marketing for AOL's 17-year-old Internet access service, price cuts for existing customers and thousands of layoffs. His goal is to devote all of AOL's energy into building its free Web-based services.

Q. Can I adjust the size of digital photos so they fit in the message window of an e-mail message?

Shrinking Photos For E-Mail    Q. When I drag digital pictures into an e-mail message, they come in huge and fill up the screen, making it impossible to see the entire image at once. Can I adjust the size of photos so they fit in the message window?    A. Giant photo syndrome can occur when the resolution of the digital picture exceeds that of the computer monitor. Although the computer's graphics software can sometimes correct the situation and reduce the image's display to fit properly on the screen, this is not always the case.

FOCUS ON THE ECONOMY Fed watchers will be out in force when the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, delivers his semiannual report to Congress on monetary policy and the state of the economy. In the first day of what is known as the Humphrey-Hawkins testimony, Mr. Bernanke will address the Senate Banking Committee; the next day he will testify to the House Financial Services Committee. With Mr. Bernanke still in his rookie year, many on Wall Street can be expected to be parsing his speech for signs of what kind of player he might turn out to be. (Wednesday and Thursday.).

FOCUS ON THE ECONOMY -- Fed watchers will be out in force when the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, delivers his semiannual report to Congress on monetary policy and the state of the economy. In the first day of what is known as the Humphrey-Hawkins testimony, Mr. Bernanke will address the Senate Banking Committee; the next day he will testify to the House Financial Services Committee. With Mr. Bernanke still in his rookie year, many on Wall Street can be expected to be parsing his speech for signs of what kind of player he might turn out to be. (Wednesday and Thursday.)    FANNIE AND FREDDIE -- At the New York Yacht Club, a few people with some strong opinions about Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the huge government-sponsored mortgage packagers, will be on hand for a panel discussion about how the two should be regulated -- or perhaps punished. Randal K. Quarles, the Treasury under secretary for domestic finance, and James B. Lockhart III, director of the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, both of whom have been outspoken about the management and accounting scandals at the two companies, will be offering their views. (Wednesday.)    A FLURRY OF REPORTS -- So many economic indicators, so little time. There will be updates on inflation with the Producer Price Index for June (Tuesday) and the Consumer Price Index for June (Wednesday). Other reports: industrial production and capacity utilization for June (Monday); June housing starts (Wednesday); and Federal Reserve minutes for June and the Conference Board's leading economic indicators (Thursday).    EARNINGS DRUMBEAT -- Earnings season gets into full swing this week, starting on Monday with Citigroup. Tuesday's roster will include Coca-Cola, I.B.M., Johnson & Johnson, Merrill Lynch, United Technologies and Yahoo. On Wednesday: AMR, Apple Computer, Bank of America, eBay, General Dynamics, Intel, J. P. Morgan Chase, Motorola, Southwest Airlines and UnitedHealth Group. Thursday: Advanced Micro Devices, Ford Motor, Google, Honeywell, Microsoft, Nokia, Pfizer, SAP, Wachovia and Wyeth. And on Friday: Caterpillar and Eli Lilly.

SHOWDOWN OVER STEM CELLS -- The United States Senate defied a veto threat by President Bush and approved legislation that would expand federal support of medical research using embryonic stem cells. White House officials said Mr. Bush planned to veto the measure, ignoring substantial support from Senate Republicans. [Page A1.]    INCHING FORWARD ON RESEARCH -- A bill approved by the Senate to bolster stem cell research is expected to help ease restrictions that have burdened laboratories with red tape, reduced American competitiveness and discouraged young researchers from entering the field. But the legislation by itself would not immediately provide an overall increase in money for the research. [A18.]    YAHOO IN A SLIDE -- Shares of Yahoo fell to their lowest level in nearly two years in after-hours trading as it reported weak revenue from Internet search advertising in the second quarter and a delay in a project meant to match the technology of Google, its chief rival. [C1.]    FRONT-PAGE NEWS, AND ADS -- The Wall Street Journal confirmed long-standing speculation that it would open its front page to advertisers, probably in September, a move that could bring in tens of millions of dollars a year in ad revenue. The ad, informally called a ''jewel box'' and to appear in the bottom right corner, will showcase some of the paper's most valued advertisers. [C1.]    A FOX MORNING TALK SHOW -- Beginning in January, the 35 stations in the Fox group will broadcast a live morning show, to be seen at 9 a.m. in most cities. The show, with Juliet Huddy, left, and Mike Jerrick, currently the hosts of ''DaySide'' on Fox News, will generally forgo hard news for segments on entertainment and lifestyle. [E1.]    BOOM IN PRIVATE PRISONS -- As the country gets tougher on illegal immigration and increases enforcement, some of the biggest beneficiaries may be the companies that have been building and running private prisons. By late next year, the administration expects that about 27,500 immigrants will be in detention each night. At an average cost of $95 a night, that adds up to nearly $1 billion a year. [C1.]    DISNEY TIGHTENS ITS BELT -- The Walt Disney Company said it would eliminate 650 jobs, change some of its top managers and trim the number of movies it releases to 12 to 13 a year, from about 18. [C1.]    STRONG QUARTER FOR MERRILL -- Quarterly profit at Merrill Lynch climbed 42 percent, aided by a strong performance in stock trading despite a downturn in the markets. Merrill Lynch said it had a profit of $1.58 billion, compared with $1.14 billion in the second quarter of 2005. Revenue increased 29 percent, to $8.2 billion. [C4.]    BATTLE OF THE MICROPROCESSORS -- Advanced Micro Devices, with Phil Hester as its technology officer, has regained some of the market share it had lost to Intel, but the battle for supremacy in producing ever-faster microprocessors has only intensified. Intel has been fighting back with discounts and new designs. [C7.]    THE STAKES GET BIGGER -- The online gambling industry was thrown into turmoil after the federal government arrested a top executive from a London betting company, leaving his competitors wondering whether they could be next. Stock prices of the industry's biggest names, including PartyGaming and SportingBet, plummeted on fears that companies could face charges of criminal racketeering. [C5.]    COMPLETING AN ERRATIC COURSE -- The V-22 Osprey, a helicopter-airplane hybrid made specifically for the United States Marine Corps, made its public debut at an air show in England. At a cost 0f $70 million each, its makers, Bell Helicopter and Boeing, hope it can overcome a troubled 20-year history. [C4.]    AN UNEXPECTED WHOLESALE RISE -- Higher costs of food and energy pushed up wholesale prices in June to an unexpectedly high level, leaving economists to debate whether prices might be rising too quickly. The Labor Department said that the Producer Price Index rose 0.5 percent in June, after a 0.2 percent increase in May. Microsoft reported a 16 percent increase in quarterly sales but flat profit, as it spent heavily to catch up to Google in Internet search and advertising. A Microsoft executive characterized the added spending as an investment in the ''next wave of growth for the company.'' Bowing to pressure from investors, Microsoft announced that it planned to spend up to $40 billion buying its own shares to lift its stock price. The company's stock price rose 5 percent after the news was released.     Article, Page C3

INTERNATIONAL A3-11    U.S. Marines Enter Beirut To Evacuate Americans  Marines landed in Beirut for the first time in more than 20 years to help evacuate Americans from Lebanon, as Israeli officials suggested that Israeli ground troops might take a more active role in combating the Hezbollah militia.   A1    The morbid reality of Israel's bombing campaign of southern Lebanon is reaching almost every corner of the city of Tyre.   A9    More Iraqis Flee Their Homes  Relentless sectarian violence is forcing Iraqi families to flee their homes in larger and larger numbers, according to figures released by the Iraqi government.   A6    In a measure of the spread of Baghdad's sectarian war, Sunni Arab militants in Baghdad have forced all but one bakery in the northern part of the city to close, leaving the area bereft of fresh bread, the simplest of Iraqi needs.   A1    Iran Warns Against Sanctions  Iran promised again to respond to a package of incentives on Aug. 22 but warned that it would reconsider its position if its case was sent to the United Nations Security Council.   A4    Putin Honors K.G.B. Agents  President Vladimir V. Putin awarded medals to members of the former K.G.B. for what the Kremlin said was their role in the killing of the Chechen terrorist leader Shamil Basayev this month.   A3    NATIONAL A12-17    In Speech to N.A.A.C.P., Bush Offers Reconciliation  In his first speech to the N.A.A.C.P. since taking office in 2001, President Bush acknowledged that ''many African Americans distrust my party,'' and defended his record on a range of domestic issues, including education and Hurricane Katrina.   A16    Voting Rights Act Is Extended  The Senate voted to extend the landmark Voting Rights Act as lawmakers of both parties said federal supervision was still required to protect the ability of minorities and the disadvantaged to cast ballots in some regions of the country.   A16    EDUCATION    SAT Errors Report Released  The College Board should acquire better scanning software, increase training for test center personnel and make other improvements in its procedures to help prevent errors in scoring SAT exams, according to a report.   A17    SCIENCE/HEALTH    A Closer Look at Neanderthals  German researchers plan to collaborate with an American company to try to reconstruct the genome of Neanderthals, the archaic human species that occupied Europe until being displaced by modern humans.   A14    NEW YORK/REGION B1-6    An Empire at Ground Zero, Not the Emperor Himself  Signs of the construction empire owned by Dino Tomassetti Sr., which is building the foundation at ground zero, are widespread. But Mr. Tomassetti, who has been linked to organized crime, is barred from receiving city contracts and banned from the site. The site's developer says he will make sure that Mr. Tomassetti does not profit from his company's role in the project. The move came as residents complained that the city has ignored them.  B1    Settlement in Zongo Case  Relatives of Ousmane Zongo, an African immigrant who was shot dead by a police officer during a raid on a labyrinthine storage warehouse in Chelsea, settled a lawsuit against the city for $3 million. Google's profits more than doubled in the second quarter, as the company continued to increase its share of the lucrative search advertising market.      The company, which announced results yesterday, exceeded analysts' expectations for both sales and profit. That is in contrast to Yahoo, which disappointed Wall Street Tuesday with lower-than-expected revenue from search-related advertising. Yahoo met profit expectations because it postponed some hiring and advertising spending.

When Google introduced its mapping service last year, it did something that made its competitors look antiquated. Users could click on a map and drag it to see an adjacent area, a much faster approach than those offered by rival mapping services.      But today, Google Maps still does not offer some of the pedestrian conveniences of Yahoo Maps and MapQuest from AOL. For example, it does not remember addresses, so users need to tell it where they live every time they want driving directions.

INTERNATIONAL   A3-11    Israel Mulls Outside Force To Patrol Lebanon Border  As Israel pounded southern Lebanon and the Hezbollah militia rained dozens more rockets on Israel's north, diplomatic efforts increased with growing discussion of a multinational armed force being set up in the area. The Israeli prime minister spoke of a force consisting of European Union members with combat experience and the authority to take control of Lebanon's border and crossing points.   A1    Israeli warplanes hit civilians escaping by vehicle from their villages in southern Lebanon at least six times in a series of fierce bombardments, witnesses and officials said. Lebanese Red Cross ambulance drivers complained about narrowly avoiding Israeli fire as they cleared out the wounded, and a Lebanese photographer was killed when an Israeli missile struck near her car. A1    Saudis Urge Cease-Fire  A delegation from Saudi Arabia asked President Bush to push for a cease-fire in the war between Israel and the terrorist group Hezbollah. The foreign minister said he delivered a letter from the Saudi king, Abdullah, with suggestions for ending the violence. It met a cool reception from American Officials.  A8    Syrian Calls U.S. Course Faulty  The Bush administration's approach of indirectly pressuring Syria to drop support for Hezbollah is doomed to failure, said Bthaina Shaaban a top Syrian minister. Washington, she says, is ignoring reality if it thinks groups like Hezbollah and Hamas can be purged by allowing Israel to bomb at will.  A9    Recruitment Troubles in Iraq  Recruiting a new police force to battle the insurgents in Iraq has become a central element in the United States' plan to reduce American forces. American commanders face securing a modicum of cooperation from a wary population, and to contend with a campaign by insurgents to assassinate and intimidate the members of Iraq's fledgling security services.  A10    Saddam Hussein was hospitalized after a hunger strike, and was being fed with a tube and given tests to ensure that he could continue to attend his trial, Iraqi and American officials said. Widespread sectarian violence returned after two days of relative calm, with at least 57 people killed in bombings in Baghdad and Kirkuk.  A11    Artist Shadowed by Nazi Ties  After years of obscurity, the first publicly financed exhibit since World War II of the work of Arno Breker, the German sculptor whose art so vividly expressed Nazi ideology that he became known as ''Hitler's favorite sculptor,'' is being mounted in Schwerin, Germany. The exhibit has ignited a debate in a region which has had a spurt of far-right and neo-Nazi political activity recently.  A3    NATIONAL A12-15    U.S. to Limit Payments For Victims of Disaster  The Department of Homeland Security, responding to months of criticism and ridicule, will sharply cut back on emergency cash assistance for victims of major disasters, and more carefully control access to free hotel rooms. Immediate emergency aid would not exceed $500 in cash instead of $2,000 per family under the new rules.  A1    Bar Association Critical of Bush  The American Bar Association said President Bush was flouting the Constitution and undermining the rule of law by claiming the power to disregard selected provisions of bills that he signed. In a comprehensive report, a bipartisan panel of the bar association said Mr. Bush had used such ''signing statements'' far more than his predecessor.  A12    Sunday Services in Parks  From Memorial Day to Labor Day, 42 state, national and private parks in Pennsylvania hold nondenominational Christian worship services. The chaplains come from local towns and faraway states, as do the worshipers, mostly Protestants. Last year, 18,000 people attended services in Pennsylvania parks.  A13    Elderly Katrina Victims Struggle  Thousands of elderly Hurricane Katrina evacuees still struggle to get by in cities hundreds of miles from their home in New Orleans. But more than most evacuees, it is the elderly who want most to return, say social service workers, and who have the hardest time doing so.  A12    F.D.A. to Limit Industry Ties  The Food and Drug Administration is expected to announce an effort to write guidelines detailing the kind of industry ties that are permitted for those who serve on its powerful advisory boards. The agency hopes to appease critics who have complained that board members often have such deep financial ties to drug makers that their advice is tainted.  A13    SCIENCE/HEALTH    Stomach Surgery Called Risky  Four of every 10 patients who undergo weight-loss surgery develop complications within six months, the federal government said. The number of such surgical procedures has been rising rapidly, along with the incidence of obesity, which now afflicts 30 percent of adults in the United States, health officials said.  A15    OBITUARIES B7    Thomas J. Manton  A former congressman and New York City councilman who was chairman of the powerful Queens Democratic party for the past two decades, he was 73.  B7    Walter Allner  The Bauhaus-trained graphic designer and art director of Fortune magazine from 1962 to 1974 who introduced a European modernist typographic sensibility to American magazine design, he was 97.  B7    NEW YORK/REGION B1-5    Progress Made Restoring Electricity to Queens  Consolidated Edison reported major progress in the week-old struggle to restore power to northwest Queens, but thousands faced a new work week without electricity and frustrations boiled over as some officials called for a declaration of emergency and the resignation of the utility's chief executive.  A1    Last Fishing Shop Moves  Capitol Fishing and Tackle, the last bait and tackle shop in Manhattan, is leaving the Chelsea Hotel, where it has resided for more than four decades. B1    Campaign Draws Big Names  With their race quickly becoming a national symbol of rifts in the Democratic party, Sen. Joseph I. Lieberman and his challenger, Ned Lamont, are turning to national political stars to help bolster each of their campaigns, apparently hoping that the big names can help turn out votes in the coming primary for the Senate.  B1    SPORTSMONDAY D1-8    Tiger Woods Wins British Open  Tiger Woods shot five-under-par 67 at the 135th British Open to win the 11th professional major championship of his career. Mr. Woods's victory gave him back-to-back British Open titles, a feat last accomplished by Tom Watson at Royal Birkdale in 1983. Chris DiMarco shot 68 to finish second. D1    Landis Wins Tour de France  Floyd Landis secured his first Tour de France victory, finishing the three-week, 2,267-mile race 57 seconds ahead of Oscar Pereiro of Spain. Mr. Landis kept the trophy in American hands after Lance Armstrong won it seven straight times before retiring.  D1    ARTS E1-8    Bitter Breach for Pilobolus  Pilobolus Dance Theater has become embroiled in a bitter dispute with the choreographer Alison Chase. Ms. Chase, who was one of the company's four artistic directors, broke away last fall after a bitter exchange of letters by lawyers. The dispute has split current and former trustees and company members.  E1    BUSINESS DAY C1-8    Amvescap to Buy W.L. Ross  Amvescap, a global investment company based in London, is acquiring W.L. Ross & Company, owned by the investor Wilbur Ross. Mr. Ross will remain with the company and manage Amvescap's private-equity business.  C1    Macy's Reality TV Debut  A new reality television series called ''Unwrapping Macy's,'' is the latest contribution to the emerging genre of corporate TV docudramas and appears to be the first reality show to revolve around an American retailer.  C1    Internet Search Business  The different approaches used by Google and Yahoo have defined a key front in the battle for online loyalty in the Internet search business. Yahoo tends to offer services that are consistent and predictable while Google has made a conscious choice to downplay copycat features, offering more innovative services.  C1    Panasonic's New Plasma TV  Panasonic said that it would begin selling a 103-inch flat-panel plasma television in the United States in time for the holiday season. The TV, about as big as a queen-size bed and, Panasonic says, the largest on the market, will sell for $70,000. 8 P.M. (BET) DON'T TRIP . . . HE AIN'T THROUGH WITH ME YET! -- Mr. Zoot Suit, the comedian Steve Harvey (above), keeps it clean as he revels in faith, family, preachers and relationships in this stand-up routine taped before church folk at Bishop T. D. Jakes's MegaFest, a four-day evangelical festival in Atlanta. Listen up: underneath the laugh lines lurk words of wisdom.    8 P.M. (Showtime) DIARY OF A MAD BLACK WOMAN (2005). Hell hath no fury, especially when Madea is working on behalf of the scorned. In this adaptation of his revenge play about a woman whose husband of 18 years boots her out of their mansion, Tyler Perry revs up his gun-packing, extra-extra- large grandmother, whose idea of dividing community property requires a chain saw.    9 P.M. (Discovery) DIRTY JOBS: JOBS THAT BITE . . . HARDER -- Mike Rowe mingles with people who earn their livings working with toothy terrors, including some that make plaster molds of live sharks for fiberglass replicas and others who make shark-proof diving suits. Problem is, it's his turn to test the things. (Cue the ''Jaws'' theme.)    9 P.M. (13) BILL MOYERS ON FAITH AND REASON -- Why does an elementary teacher reared in New York and schooled at Miss Porter's and Berkeley decide to become a Buddhist nun? Tonight, in this series' eighth and last installment, Pema Chodron (above right) talks with Mr. Moyers about the spiritual search that led her to this ancient Eastern practice, and why more and more harried Westerners are turning to it in an effort to slow down.    9 P.M. (TLC) WHAT NOT TO WEAR -- Nancy G., a 34-year-old single mother, dresses like she feels, in worn-out cardigans and flannel pajama pants. Stacy and Clinton help wake up her wardrobe.    9 P.M. (USA) MONK -- Natalie persuades Monk to go into business as a private eye, but his first case, a fender bender, is no mere bump in the road.    9 P.M. (BBC America) EDDIE IZZARD: GLORIOUS -- No topic is off-limits in this taping from Mr. Izzard's 1997 stand-up tour, in which he sputters and spews out one-liners like a human equivalent of Google. His riff on air terror, in which the evildoer is a cookie-snatching pilot, may not hit the same comic heights these days. But if you're not laughing with Mr. Izzard (above), you'll be laughing at him, or at least his get-up: shiny apple-red suit, frosted shag and glittery fingernails.    10 P.M. (Discovery) SCIENCE OF SHARK SEX -- Gray sharks mating. You may want to cover your eyes.   KATHRYN SHATTUCK

A SALE AT FORBES -- The Forbes family has sold a significant minority stake in a newly formed company, Forbes Media -- which includes Forbes magazine, the Forbes.com Web site and a number of smaller media properties -- to Elevation Partners, a private equity group. [C1.]    EXPECTING A PAUSE -- After a string of 17 consecutive interest rate increases, the Federal Reserve may pause this week in its long campaign of monetary tightening, which has lifted the benchmark federal funds rate to 5.25 percent, from 1 percent in June 2004. At least that is what most investors have come to believe. [C1.]    CLERKS ON THE WEB -- Internet retailers are increasingly adding online chat specialists who lurk in the background and wait for signs that someone needs just the slightest nudge to buy an item. Paco Underhill, right, a retailing consultant, said: ''Making this process social is important, because the acquisition of goods has never been just about the acquisition of goods. There's always been a social element to it.'' Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C9.]    GOOGLE AD DEAL -- Google has struck a deal to allow Web site owners to put video clips from Viacom, including ''SpongeBob SquarePants'' and MTV's ''Laguna Beach: The Real Orange County,'' on their pages. The clips will be accompanied by advertising, with Viacom, Google and site owners dividing ad revenue. [C1.]    THE FADING PICTURE TUBE -- The bulky, squarish, heavy picture tube is heading for the dustbin of history much faster than anyone expected. This year, the number of TV models in the United States that use glass cathode-ray tubes to produce an image has been reduced sharply. By next year, even fewer C.R.T. televisions will be made, and fewer retailers will sell them. [C1.]    MOVIE MARKETING, TRANSLATED -- As Hollywood increasingly looks overseas to bolster the bottom line, studios are finding that the rules that apply to movie marketing and distribution in the United States -- calling for a barrage of talk-show interviews and television advertising -- do not necessarily translate in Hamburg, Tokyo or Moscow. [C1.]    DEBATING WIKIPEDIA'S FUTURE -- As hard-core Wikipedia contributors gathered during the weekend to consider the next phase of the online encyclopedia's life cycle, Jimmy Wales, the site's founder, said that the emphasis going forward would be on quality, not quantity. [C4.]    FREE PAPERS IN EUROPE -- When Metro International, a publisher of free newspapers, moved into France four years ago, established competitors cried foul. Now Metro and other free papers are fixtures of the French cityscape, reflecting a broader shift across Europe, as upstart free papers continue their rapid growth. And publishers of existing papers, casting about for any way to retain readers, are increasingly turning to giveaways. [C6.]    SATIRE STARTS A FEUD -- A satire in a German newspaper aimed at the twin brothers who now head the Polish government has sparked a cross-border feud over the role of the press. [C6.]    AD MAKEOVER AT MONTBLANC -- Montblanc is paying up-and-coming designers to put their names, and their clothing, on a new crop of ads appearing in the September issue of Vogue. It is a May-December relationship, in which Montblanc, the venerable company famed for its high-end pens, will share glossy ad space with youthful designers whose mere presence adds an element of cool. Advertising. [C6.]    NEW TERRITORY FOR CABLE -- The biggest names in cable and satellite television are poised to get into mobile phone and wireless data services. [C8.]    CLAMORING TO GET INSIDE CUBA -- With one of the biggest stories in Cuban history now unfolding, many news organizations in the United States are scrambling to cover events in a Communist country that bars most American reporters. [C5.]    CHAIN BUYS COLLEGE PAPER -- Last week The Tallahassee Democrat, a daily paper owned by Gannett, announced that it had purchased a college newspaper. Media industry analysts said that it seemed to be the first time that a college paper had been bought by a major chain. [C5.]

INTERNATIONAL A3-10    Lebanese Offer to Deploy Troops Dismissed by Israel  Lebanon's government, including two Hezbollah ministers, offered to deploy 15,000 of its troops to the south if Israel withdrew its forces. Israel insisted that its troops would remain until an international force capable of halting Hezbollah missile strikes into Israel is in place.  A8    Hezbollah rocket fire in the north of Israel has ignited hundreds of fires in the few forests in the Galilee region. Officials estimated that as much as 3,000 acres of forest has been damaged by fire from the rockets.  A9    In Iraq, Striving for a Cool Phone  According to the State Department, there are now 7.1 million cellphone subscribers in Iraq. Iraqis of all sects rely on their phones as a means of communication to avoid danger, as well as a means of self-expression. As a status symbol certain phones are given names, like ''Apache,'' and have price tags reaching $800.  A1    Cubans Expect Rapid Recovery  High-ranking Cuban officials, working hard to put out the message that Cuba is stable after the transfer of power from Fidel Castro to his younger brother, said that Mr. Castro was recovering and that he would be able to return to duty ''in a short time.'' A4    Flood in Ethiopia Kills 191  A flash flood in Dire Dawa, in eastern Ethiopia, swept away houses, factories and dozens of people over the weekend, killing at least 191, with 300 more still missing, officials said. A6    Taiwan Loses Another Ally  Taiwan's foreign minister warned that Beijing's establishment of diplomatic relations with Chad, one of Taiwan's few remaining allies, would hurt relations with China.  A6    NATIONAL A12-15    Ohio Congressman Will Not Seek Re-election  Representative Bob Ney, left, an Ohio Republican entangled in the corruption scandal centered on the former lobbyist Jack Abramoff, announced that he would abandon his bid for re-election.   A15    DeLay to Stay on Ballot  The Supreme Court dealt a final blow to efforts by the Texas Republican Party to replace former Representative Tom DeLay on the Congressional ballot in November, leaving him the reluctant party nominee from his longtime district.   A15    Fighting Crime in New Orleans  After months of chaos in the criminal justice system, Mayor C. Ray Nagin of New Orleans announced the first steps to replace the city's missing prosecutors, public defenders and police officers, along with its ruined courtrooms.   A12    Phoenix Man Claims Innocence  One of two men charged in a series of killings in Phoenix told reporters that he was innocent and that his roommate might have taken his car and guns to commit the crimes.   A12    SCIENCE TIMES F1-8    The Seafloor as Gas Trap  A team of researchers propose what they say is a limitless, low-risk repository for carbon dioxide, the heat-trapping gas emitted by power plants: seafloor sediments at depths and temperatures that would guarantee the gas would be permanently locked away. F3    Health & Fitness F5    NEW YORK/REGION B1-6    Senate Rivals Shift Tactics In Last Day of Campaigning  As Connecticut voters prepared for their highly anticipated Democratic primary, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman and Ned Lamont, the rivals for United States Senate, used sharply different tactics in seeking a final advantage in a contest that appeared to be tightening.  A1    Audit Faults Fiscal Practices  State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, in the latest stinging audit of a Long Island school district, has accused the superintendent of the William Floyd School District of dispensing raises to himself and other administrators, awarding no-bid contracts, and overseeing millions of dollars in ''inappropriate'' expenditures.  B1    Brewery Moves to Newark  Rolling Rock Beer, a longtime staple of Latrobe in the mountains of western Pennsylvania, will soon begin brewing in the Anheseur-Busch plant on Routes 1 and 9 in the shadow of Newark Liberty International Airport in Newark.  B1    SPORTSTUESDAY D1-6    Landis Defends Performance  Floyd Landis set out on a vigorous public relations campaign, speaking to about a dozen television stations and newspapers, to declare that he did not use performance-enhancing drugs to win the Tour de France. D3    ARTS E1-10    Foundation Selects New Leader  The Barnes Foundation announced that it had appointed a prominent Philadelphia arts figure as its executive director, ending a 14-month search. E1    BUSINESS DAY C1-12    BP Shuts Down Oil Field  BP began shutting down the nation's largest oil field after an inspection detected heavy corrosion and a small leak in a critical pipeline in its Alaskan Prudhoe Bay operation. The emergency drove already high world crude oil prices to $77 a barrel.   A1    Pension Plan Shortages  Across the nation, states, counties and municipalities may owe their current and future retirees roughly $375 billion more than they have committed to their pension funds.   A1    Google Has MySpace Deal  Google won a bidding war to provide search services and advertising to MySpace.com and other Web sites owned by the News Corporation. Google promised to pay a minimum of $900 million. PIPELINE LEAK SENDS OIL HIGHER -- BP began shutting down the nation's largest oil field after an inspection detected heavy corrosion and a small leak in a critical pipeline in its Alaskan Prudhoe Bay operation. The emergency drove already-high world crude oil prices to just under $77 a barrel. BP said it could not estimate how long the system would be down. [Page A1.]    STOCKS FALL ON OIL WORRIES -- Stocks declined as crude oil surged after BP began shutting down its field in Alaska for emergency repairs. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.59 points, to 1275.77. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 20.97 points, to 11,219.38. The Nasdaq lost 12.55 points, to 2,072.50. [C12.]    SHORTCHANGING PUBLIC PENSIONS -- A number of states, counties and municipalities have engaged in maneuvers similar to the city worker pension fund in San Diego, which, after being underfunded, set off a wave of lawsuits, investigations and eventually criminal indictments. But now with millions of people flocking to see that exhibition and others like it, a ghastly new underground cadaver industry has emerged in China. CLEARED IN RETIREMENT CASE -- A three-judge appellate panel ruled that I.B.M. did not discriminate against its older workers when it switched retirement plans in 1999, a decision that could help shelter hundreds of companies from possible age-discrimination suits. COMPUTER BATTERIES RECALLED -- Dell is recalling 4.1 million notebook computer batteries because they could erupt in flames, the company said. It will be the largest safety recall in the history of the consumer electronics industry, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said. The recall raises broader questions about lithium-ion batteries, which are used in a host of other devices. [Page A1.]    PEPSICO NAMES NEW CHIEF -- PepsiCo said that its president and chief financial officer, Indra K. Nooyi, left, would succeed Steven S. Reinemund as chief executive on Oct. 1. Ms. Nooyi, 50, who was born in India, will be PepsiCo's fifth chief executive in its 41-year history, and the first woman. Her promotion will make Pepsico, with $33 billion in sales, the largest United States company by market value led by a woman, and the third-largest by revenue, behind Archer Daniels Midland and Kraft Foods. Sherman, the owner of a generic drug maker, has seemingly outsmarted Bristol-Myers and Sanofi-Aventis to market the first generic form of the drug Plavix five years before its patent expires. Now the Department of Justice is investigating whether Bristol and Sanofi tried to conceal part of a deal they were negotiating with Mr. Sherman to settle a lawsuit on the validity of their patent. KATRINA INSURANCE RULING A federal judge in Mississippi sided with home insurance companies and ruled that they do not have to pay for the flooding that destroyed tens of thousands of homes in Hurricane Katrina. [C1.]    THE SCIENCE OF BATTERIES In trying to improve the endurance of batteries, scientists cannot overcome some basic hurdles of chemistry and physics. The more energy that is stored in a smaller package, the more volatile and dangerous that package becomes. The volatility of some batteries became clear with Dell's recall of 4.1 million laptop batteries. Dell said the batteries, made by Sony, could catch fire. Late last month, an array of General Electric executives stood before about 100 analysts and attempted to prove that all of G.E.'s wildly disparate units march to the same tune. In a sense, G.E. was preaching to the choir, with most analysts covering G.E. rating its shares a buy. But investors are not heeding the advice. For more than a year, analysts have predicted that the stock would reach $40 or more. Instead, it has hovered around the mid-30's. When people search the Internet in their homes, it feels like a private activity. But as AOL reminded the world this month, when it made public 19 million search queries by customers, companies often store searches in ways that allow them to be traced back to specific users. The storing and sharing of data of this kind is a violation of users' privacy rights. The U.S. Congress, the Federal Trade Commission and the companies should do more to protect these rights.

Chris Gladwin, a software designer and businessman in Chicago, had time on his hands after selling his company, the online music store Music Now, in 2004. So he decided to digitize all of the music, photos and paper detritus that he had been meaning to organize for years.     After he was finished, he discovered that he had 27 gigabytes of data -- equivalent to a library of 22,000 books -- that he was eager to protect. ''I wondered, 'what are my options?' '' he said, ''and I realized that none of them were that good.''

But as AOL reminded the world this month, when it made public 19 million search queries by customers, companies often store searches in ways that allow them to be traced back to specific users. The storing and sharing of data of this kind is a violation of users' privacy rights. Congress, the Federal Trade Commission and the companies should do more to protect these rights.      When people talk on the phone, they assume that the words they utter will disappear when the call is over. They certainly do not expect that their phone company is recording and storing the words, to mine for commercial purposes or to sell to other companies. People have the same expectation about the Internet searches they do: when the search is over, the words they used will disappear.

Knowledge, Samuel Johnson once said, ''is of two kinds. We know a subject ourselves, or we know where we can find information upon it.'' The point behind every scheme for cataloging books -- and there are more schemes than you'd imagine -- is to make the second kind of knowledge easier to come by. Most experienced library users know the Library of Congress classification system, at least in its outlines. But the reference collection in the Main Reading Room at the New York Public Library follows the Billings system, created by a former director of the library and used nowhere else. It is a map on which you recognize none of the symbols.     That is all changing, at last. The reference collection is being reshelved according to the Library of Congress system. In the overall history of information science, this may seem like a leap from the 1890's to the late 1890's. But a classification system is like a shark. If it isn't moving forward, it's probably dead. Perhaps the most delightfully named branch of the federal bureaucracy is the Library of Congress Cataloging Directorate, which sounds oddly like an office of totalitarian librarians. One division of the Cataloging Directorate does nothing but keep the classification system up to date. The same cannot be said of the Billings system, which suffered obsolescence long ago.

When Eric E. Schmidt, Google's chief executive, was named to Apple Computer's board this week, it did more than signal a potential alliance between powerful companies. It touched off a wave of speculation about the motives of the man behind the move: Apple's co-founder, Steven P. Jobs. INTERNATIONAL   A3-14    Peace in Darfur at Risk, As New Conflict Looms  Negotiations over a proposed United Nations force to shore up the shaky peace in Darfur have limped along with no sign of compromise. The opposing sides in the conflict now seem headed toward a large-scale military confrontation.    A1    Allies Ready Sanctions for Iran  With Iran defying the deadline to halt production of nuclear fuel, the United States and three European allies are assembling a list of sanctions they would seek in the United Nations Security Council that would begin by restricting imports of nuclear material.    A1    52 Die in Iraq Sectarian Attacks  Shootings and hidden bombs at an Iraqi market, a gas station and an army recruiting center killed at least 52 people, continuing a wave of sectarian violence that has claimed roughly 200 lives this week. Despite the spike in violence, the top United States general in Iraq said Iraqi forces could take over security as early as next year.    A10    Israel Spurns U.N. Request  Israel's prime minister, Ehud Olmert, rebuffed a request from the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, for even a partial lifting of the seven-week-old blockade of Lebanon to allow Beirut's airport to resume normal operations.    A12    A continuing Israeli offensive in the Gaza Strip killed nine people, including four civilians, one of them a 14-year-old. Israelis announced the discovery of a 150-yard tunnel stretching from a house toward the Karni cargo crossing, which Israel had closed due to security alerts, between Gaza and Israel.    A14    Sri Lanka Blamed in Aid Killings  Swedish-led cease-fire monitors accused the Sri Lankan government security forces of killing 17 aid workers in the town of Mutur in one of the worst attacks against humanitarian workers worldwide in recent years. The monitors cited several reasons, including confidential conversations with ''highly reliable sources'' that they said pointed to the culpability of the security forces.    A12    ARTS   E1-10    Fake Letter in Poet's Biography  A. N. Wilson, one of London's most visible literary figures, was duped into printing a made-up love letter in ''Betjeman,'' his book about the British poet laureate John Betjeman. In the fake document, the first letters of each sentence, except the first, spell out an insulting sentence that starts with Mr. Wilson's name and ends with a vulgarity.    E1    Chicago Critic Criticized  Hedy Weiss, a theater critic for The Chicago Sun-Times for more than 20 years, is facing criticism herself after publishing scathing comments about a weekend-long festival of musicals in progress, called Stages. INTERIOR AGENCY CRITICIZED -- The inspector general of the Interior Department accused top agency officials of tolerating widespread ethical failures, from cronyism to cover-ups of incompetence, and then dismissing criticisms with ''a promise not to do it again.'' [Page A1.]    GOOGLE'S APPROACH TO CHARITY -- Larry Page, left, and Sergey Brin, founders of Google, have set up a philanthropy, giving it seed money of about $1 billion and a mandate to tackle poverty, disease and global warming. But unlike most charities, this one will be for-profit, allowing it to fund start-up companies, form partnerships with venture capitalists, and even lobby Congress. It will also pay taxes. [A1.]    WOLFOWITZ'S CORRUPTION FIGHT -- As president of the World Bank, Paul D. Wolfowitz has made the fight against corruption in poor countries a hallmark issue, and he has drawn criticism for an aggressive campaign that has led to the suspension of hundreds of millions of dollars in loans and contracts to countries including India, Chad and Bangladesh. [C1.]    U.S. WARNS CHINA -- In the administration's toughest warning yet to China on economic issues, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. said that Chinese leaders were imperiling their nation's future by engaging in policies that Americans and others see as unfair. [C3.]    NINTENDO TO RELEASE CONSOLE -- Nintendo of Japan plans to announce that it will release its new Wii video game console in North America and South America on Nov. 19, just as the holiday shopping season begins, and that the machine will cost $250 in the United States. The move may allow Nintendo to take advantage of stumbles by its main rival, Sony. [C1.]    MICROSOFT VS. HACKER -- A solitary computer hacker has entangled Microsoft in a battle of wits by repeatedly releasing a free program to strip away the software lock that the company created to protect digital movies and songs from being freely copied by Internet users. [C5.]    HIGH HOPES FOR ONLINE GAME -- AOL and Mark Burnett, producer for reality television, kicked off an ambitious online game called ''Gold Rush,'' which they hope will become a national sensation somewhat on par with the one Mr. Burnett created six years ago with the ''Survivor'' series. [C3.]    STRONG EARNINGS AT LEHMAN -- Lehman posted strong third-quarter results amid weak markets, lackluster deal flow and higher global interest rates, and its shares surged. [C13.]    MARKETS RISE -- Stocks rose, sending major indexes to their highest levels since May, as battered energy shares like Exxon Mobil rebounded and investors bet that interest rates would not rise any time soon. [C13.]    ROUGH TIME FOR NISSAN CHIEF -- Despite Carlos Ghosn's gilded reputation, his companies, Renault and its partner, Nissan Motor Corporation, are not performing well right now -- a fact their boss readily acknowledges. [C1.]    CHICAGO WAGE EFFORT FAILS -- The first attempt in the nation to impose minimum wage regulations on big-box stores like Wal-Mart unraveled as Chicago's City Council fell three votes short of overriding Mayor Richard M. Daley's veto. [A18.]    PLAN FOR JOBLESS INSURANCE -- The unemployment insurance system, which has hardly changed since its inception in 1935, should be revamped to aid more workers displaced by a transforming economy, economists said as they released overhaul plans. [A21.]    HELP FOR WHITE-COLLAR WORKERS -- Barbara Ehrenreich, author of ''Nickel and Dimed,'' has started an organization called United Professionals to help white-collar workers, be they unemployed, uninsured, downsized, stressed out or merely anxious. [A21.]    H.P. AND SPYING CASE -- California prosecutors looking into the Hewlett-Packard spying case are focusing on a small private investigation firm operating out of a house in suburban Boston. It is not clear how such a tiny firm ended up handling work for H.P., one of the largest technology companies. But other private investigators said it was not surprising, because corporations who are in need of such services often end rely on subcontractors. [C1.]    TRIAL SET FOR DIRECT MARKETER -- The lawsuit in which the coupon company Valassis Communications seeks to cancel its $1.3 billion merger agreement with the direct-mail marketer Advo will go to trial in December, a judge ruled. [C5.]    ONLINE    A BANK REBUILDS -- Gary Rivlin of The Times spoke with chief executive of Liberty Bank, Alden J. McDonald Jr., about struggling to rebuild after Hurricane Katrina. The gunman died after exchanging shots with police.  A17    Resistance to Rape Law  The Pakistani government has run into difficulties, including a postponed vote, in its efforts to pass a law to end the worst abuses suffered by women who report rape or are accused of adultery under an Islamic ordinance.  A8    Report Criticizes Hezbollah  Amnesty International accused Hezbollah of war crimes and ''serious violations of international humanitarian law'' during the Lebanon war. In August the group criticized Israel's behavior during the war.  A17    Chinese Storm Claims Disputed  China's emergency response to Typhoon Saomai in August was trumpeted as a triumph. But an internal report by the official New China News Agency, compiled in the days after the storm and intended just for the authorities, bluntly contradicted the official picture.  A3      NATIONAL A18-25    Some Movement Is Seen On National Security Plans  The White House took a critical step in its effort to get Congressional blessing for President Bush's domestic eavesdropping program, but it ran into increasingly fierce resistance from leading Republicans over its plan to try terror suspects being held at Guant√°namo Bay.  A1    Pet Projects Rule Is Delayed  Leaders of the House of Representatives postponed consideration of a rule requiring individual lawmakers to sign their names to some of the pet projects they tuck into major tax and spending bills.  A22    Big-Box Wage Rule Fails  The first efforts to impose minimum-wage regulations on big-box stores like Wal-Mart unraveled in Chicago, as its City Council fell three votes short of overriding Mayor Richard M. Daley's veto of the measure.  A18    Push to Repeal Military Law  Gay rights groups are making the biggest push in nearly a decade to repeal a 1993 law, known as ''Don't Ask, Don't Tell,'' that bars openly gay people from serving in the military.  A18    Border Fence Plan in House  House Republicans announced that they would move swiftly to pass legislation requiring the Bush administration to build 700 miles of fencing along the Mexican border to help stem the flow of illegal immigrants and drugs.  A24    NEW YORK/REGION B1-6    An Immigrant's Tale Turns Out to Be Just That  Genealogical researchers have uncovered the truth about Annie Moore, the immigrant memorialized by bronze statues in New York Harbor and in Ireland. She was indeed the first immigrant to set foot on Ellis Island -- but she did not, as legend has it, go to Texas, marry a descendant of the Irish liberator Daniel O'Connell and die under the wheels of a streetcar.  A1    A Letter From a Priest  A letter written in 1984 by Msgr. Charles M. Kavanagh, the former chief fund-raiser for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, to the parents of a man who accuses the priest of abusing him as a teenager has resurfaced. The man says the letter shows that Monsignor Kavanagh touched him in a sexual manner.  B1    Thoughts on Longevity  Asian women in Bergen County, N.J., -- who live longer than any other ethnic subgroup of people anywhere in the nation, according to federal statistics -- attribute their longevity to a healthy diet, belief in God and their close-knit communities. I learned to drive in a state where the roads are laid out in a square-mile grid. The town I learned to drive in was laid out in a grid too, except for a single, exotic, curving street. The landscape itself was a compass of sorts, and nearly all the adults I knew -- especially the farmers -- spoke of it that way. As a result, I grew up with a keen sense of direction, which is a liability only when I actually get lost. That happens once or twice a year, usually in the mildew hollows of eastern Connecticut and usually when my wife and I are already late for dinner. I get angry at myself for being lost. My wife gets angry at me for getting angry. The only solution is to get found.      Recently, I rented a car in Kansas, a state that, in the eastern sections at least, is less gridlike than it looks. I planned to do a lot of back-road driving, but I didn't have time to print up a stack of Google maps, and I didn't have a Kansas Gazetteer either. So, on a whim, I asked for a car with a G.P.S. guidance system. I knew all about the technology behind G.P.S. -- the array of satellites overhead, the tracking stations, the reliance on minute differences in time to calculate position. I own an old G.P.S. that thinks the world is a blank gray slate on which you can trace your footsteps. But I had never used one of the new generation of automotive navigation tools, which include a database of detailed road maps. Now that I have, I'm not sure I'll ever leave home without one.

As if you didn't already lavish enough attention on your Treo or BlackBerry, it's now easier than ever to spoil it rotten. You can slip it into a stylish case, scratch-proof its screen and connect all manner of strange and wonderful devices to make your smartphone even smarter.     Smartphones, roughly defined as cellphones that can store personal information and provide Internet access, were once clunky affairs carried only by the hopelessly geeky or the relentlessly corporate. But new devices like the BlackBerry Pearl and the Treo 700 series appear poised to make them more broadly popular, taking them from the Lincoln Town Car to the minivan and the Mini Cooper.

The king of cool jazz, Miles Davis, was posthumously inducted this week into RockWalk in Los Angeles with members of the Davis family - his wife, Frances, son, Erin Davis, and daughter, Cheryl Davis, in attendance. Film stars have long been invited to leave their handprints on the sidewalk gallery outside the Guitar Center on Sunset Boulevard, but Davis will be remembered with a bronze bust on display outside the store. Davis, who picked up the trumpet at age 13 and made his recording debut in 1947, died in 1991 at age 65. He was known for fusion and experimental jazz sounds. His many recordings include "Round About Midnight," "Birth of the Cool" and "Kind of Blue." The RockWalk was established in 1985 to honor musicians, and the artists Chris Botti and George Duke joined the Davis family at Thursday's ceremony. (AP)
