On a whiteboard in a windowless Microsoft conference room here, an elegant curve drawn by a software-testing engineer captures both five years of frustration and more recent progress.     The principle behind the curve -- that 80 percent of the consequences come from 20 percent of the causes -- is rooted in a 19th-century observation about the distribution of wealth. But it also illustrates the challenge for the builders of the next generation of Windows and Office, the world's largest-selling software packages.

LAST week, as YouTube continued its recent campaign to spit-shine its image and, perhaps, to look a little less ragtag to potential buyers (including Google, which was said to be eyeing the upstart in the $1.6 billion range), the company took a scrub bucket to some questionable political graffiti on its servers, including a video entry from the doyenne of right-wing blogs, Michelle Malkin. IMPROMPTU OPEC MEETING -- Members of OPEC plan an emergency meeting in Doha, Qatar, to see if they can hammer out the details of a tentative plan to cut oil supplies by a million barrels a day and put a floor under prices (Thursday). Over the weekend, Edmund Daukoru of Nigeria, the president of OPEC, called the drop in crude oil prices since July ''catastrophic.'' Although the 11 members of OPEC seem to agree on the need to rid world markets of excess oil, the situation gets a bit stickier from there, with countries like Iran and Venezuela vying with bigger producers like Saudi Arabia and Algeria for market share.    TOWARD A BETTER CANAL -- Panamanians will vote in a referendum over whether to add a third set of locks to the Panama Canal (Sunday). The country took over the canal from the United States in 1999, and although there seems to be broad agreement that the project would help bring the outdated canal up to modern standards -- making room for larger ships, for instance, and cutting wait times for vessels lingering offshore -- many Panamanians are skeptical. There is concern, among other things, that the government's $5.2 billion price tag for the seven-year project is a low estimate. Meanwhile, Nicaragua's president has proposed spending $18 billion to build a wider alternative to the Panama Canal.    INDICATORS DU JOUR -- For economic indicators, the focus this week will be on inflation, with the release of the Producer Price Index for September (Tuesday) and the Consumer Price Index for September (Wednesday). Other reports scheduled for release this week are industrial production and capacity utilization for September (Tuesday); housing starts for September (Wednesday); and leading economic indicators (Thursday). Morgan Chase (Wednesday); Bank of America, Citigroup, Coca-Cola, Dow Jones, Google, Honeywell, Eli Lilly, McDonald's, Nokia, Southwest Airlines, the Tribune Company and Wyeth (Thursday); and 3M and Merck (Friday).

WAL-MART NEAR CHINA DEAL -- Wal-Mart Stores, by far the largest retailer in the United States, is laying the groundwork to become the biggest foreign chain in China with the $1 billion purchase of a major Taiwanese-owned supermarket chain, Trust-Mart. The move represents a large step for Wal-Mart's strategy in China, allowing it to more than double its presence there. [C1.]    INDIAN ENGINEERS' CREDENTIALS -- In India -- once regarded as a bottomless well of low-cost, ready-to-work, English-speaking engineers -- a shortage looms. APPLE PROFIT TOPS ESTIMATES -- Apple Computer said that its fourth-quarter profit jumped 27 percent amid strong sales of Macintosh computers and iPod portable music players. Apple said brisk back-to-school sales were a major reason behind the results, which topped Wall Street estimates by a wide margin. Apple shares climbed as much as 6 percent in after-hours trading. [Page C1]    VIRTUAL WORLD ADVERTISING -- Companies including Sony BMG Music Entertainment, Sun Microsystems and Nissan are testing the next frontier in Internet advertising: placing ads into online virtual worlds like Second Life and Virtual Laguna Beach. Some online users worry that the corporate intrusion will spoil their virtual paradises. [C1]    MICROSOFT LOOKS AT CHIP DESIGN -- After wedding its software to Intel's processors for decades, Microsoft is looking to its own research labs for as a new source in future chip design. One goal of the project is to give Microsoft more control over hardware and software and the way the interact in new devices. [C3]    CONSUMER PRICES FALL -- Falling energy prices helped push consumer prices down sharply last month, but the decline did not entirely dispel inflation worries because the measure of retail prices that excludes food and energy costs held steady at a level still above the Federal Reserve's comfort zone. [C3]    NEW AD AGENCY NETWORK -- Three longtime advertising executives are joining forces to start an agency network with an entrepreneurial bent. The agency network, called the Partners Group, aims to grow by encouraging more entrepreneurs to affiliate with the three founders. Advertising [C13]    MUSIC INDUSTRY AND YOUTUBE -- Universal Music Group, Sony BMG Music Entertainment and Warner Music each acquired small stakes in YouTube as part of licensing deals just prior to the sale of the company to Google for $1.65 billion. The three companies now stand to receive as much as $50 million collectively, people involved in the deal said. [C1]    A TORRENT OF IMMIGRANT MONEY -- The flow of money from immigrants working in the United States to Latin America has become a torrent, increasing by 51 percent from two years ago to over $45 billion, according to a new study. Where 20 years ago such remittances came from four or five states, today they come nearly every state in the country, the study said. [A24]    ELI LILLY CRITICIZED -- Three doctors at the National Institutes of Health have sharply criticized Eli Lilly for its efforts to promote the use of Xigris, an expensive treatment for patients with sepsis, an often deadly blood infection. In an article in The New England Journal of Medicine, the doctors wrote that Lilly had manipulated treatment guidelines to promote Xigris at the expense of older, cheaper and equally effective treatments. [C12]    TIME WARNER CABLE SHARES -- Time Warner Cable said that it would sell shares publicly for the first time, giving investors a chance to own a piece of the country's second-largest cable provider after Comcast. The shares would amount to 16 percent of the company's equity. [C5]    EARNINGS RISE AT A.M.D. -- Advanced Micro Devices, which makes computer processors, posted a higher quarterly profit but profit margins fell sharply, hurt by a price war with the rival chipmaker Intel. Advanced Micro said it expected fourth-quarter sales to rise from the previous quarter but did not elaborate. [C4]    NBC PLANS CUTBACKS -- NBC will announce a series of cost-cutting measures including some employee layoffs, executives said. GOOGLE KEEPS ON GROWING -- Google, the world's largest search engine company, said that its profits nearly doubled from a year ago, maintaining a torrid growth rate at a time when rivals like Yahoo appeared to be faltering. Google said it earned $733 million in the third quarter, up 92 percent from a year ago. Revenue climbed to $2.69 billion, with 44 percent of that coming from outside the United States. [Page C3.]    DOW ABOVE 12,000 -- The Dow Jones industrial average closed above the psychologically important 12,000 level for the first time, indicating that investors were increasingly confident that the economy was poised to perform the rare feat of slowing without stalling. The performance in the months ahead will depend, in part, how gracefully the economy handles the slowing housing market. [C1.]    BIG BANK EARNINGS -- Citigroup seemed to stumble and Bank of America appeared to strut through a messy third quarter as the country's two biggest banks contended with pressures of a slowing economy and higher interest rates. [C3]    CBS SETTLES ACCUSATIONS -- CBS became the first radio corporation to settle accusations of illicit pay-for-play practices made by Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general. CBS, which runs approximately 180 radio stations, agreed to adopt more stringent policies on its stations' dealings with record labels and to make a $2 million payment to New York charities. [C3.]    MEDICINE VS. MARKETING -- For many doctors, it's an irresistible pitch: a $250 profit from a 15-minute test. With that lure, some 12,000 of the nation's physicians have purchased an automated device that checks patients for nerve disease. Specialists say the problem is that many general practitioners are not qualified to do such tests. [A1.]    HIGHER PROFITS AT DRUG MAKERS -- Drug makers continued to post strong profit gains, led by Pfizer, the world's biggest pharmaceutical company, which reported that its third-quarter earnings had more than doubled from a year earlier. Eli Lilly, Novartis, and Wyeth also reported higher quarterly profits. [C2]    VIDEO GAME WARS -- Laying the groundwork for a battle against rival Microsoft, Sony said that 21 games would be available for the PlayStation 3 game console when it goes on sale next month. Sony also plans to highlight the console's ability to play high-definition DVD's in Sony's Blu-ray format. [C11.]    BANNER YEAR IN HONG KONG -- In a reflection of China's growing prominence in international finance, Hong Kong is set for a banner year in global markets with more money raised by companies selling shares to the public here than on the biggest exchanges in New York and London. Pricing will be set today for the world's largest IPO ever, that of China's biggest bank, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China. [C1.]    BEYOND REGULATORS' REACH -- Every month, roughly 19,000 households across the country write check to Christian Care Ministry. The members pool their health expenses and contributions and the ministry writes checks to health care providers. Such payments totaled $57 million in the latest fiscal year. While ministry members say they are helping to carry each others burdens, some Florida state officials see what they would call unregulated health insurance. [C1.]    RULING AGAINST GRASSO -- A New York judge ruled that Richard A. Grasso, a former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, would have to return as much as $100 million of a fiercely contested $139.5 million retirement payout to the exchange The judge, Justice Charles E. Ramos of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, said that Mr. Grasso did not disclose to his fellow directors on the board of the exchange the extent to which his soaring compensation had caused his pension and savings to balloon. [A1.]    MERGER REVERBERATIONS -- The $8 billion combination of Chicago's derivatives markets is being heralded as good for Chicago and good for the exchanges. But in Europe, it is raising concerns at banks and rival exchanges that it may increase costs or stifle competition. One of the biggest fears in London where the local derivatives exchange will be dwarfed, is that it creates a so-called vertical silo, or a market where one giant entity is both a trading platform and a clearing system. [C8.]    NBC STAFF CUTBACKS -- NBC said it planned to reduce its 6,000-person newsgathering staff by an estimated 5 percent, or 300 people to adapt to the migration of news viewers to the Internet and eliminate overlaps in news coverage. Steve Capus, president of NBC News, said the bulk of the cuts would come from eliminating jobs already vacant, as well as from early retirements and voluntary buyouts, but that some layoffs were inevitable. [C4.]    LOWER COST PROGRAMMING -- As part of the extensive cost-cutting program it announced yesterday, NBC intends to dramatically alter its prime-time programming, starting in the fall of 2007, filling the 8 p.m. hour each night of the week with lower-cost, unscripted programs and saving its more expensive scripted comedies and dramas for the 9-to-11 block. [C1.]    WEAK NEWSPAPER PROFITS -- Newspaper companies continued to show weakness, with The New York Times Company and the Tribune Company both reporting lackluster earnings, citing soft advertising sales as a major culprit. At the Times Company, the slowdown ''is expected to continue through the end of the year,'' said Janet L. Robinson, the company's president and chief executive. [C7.]    ONLINE    Business Briefing  Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business.    McDonald's reported a 15 percent rise in third-quarter profitmeeting a better-than-expected forecast it gave last week. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    Travelers packed planes operated by Continental Airlines and Southwest Airlines over the summer, but Continental's third-quarter profit grew while Southwest's earnings fell in another sign that traditional carriers were narrowing the gap with low-cost rivals. SKILLING TO BE SENTENCED -- Jeffrey Skilling, the former chief executive of Enron, is scheduled to be sentenced today in federal court. Most legal experts are betting that Judge Simeon T. Lake will give Mr. Skilling a sentence of at least 25 years for his role in heading a conspiracy to defraud Enron investors. If it exceeds that, it would be the longest sentence ever handed down for a white-collar crime. [C1.]    FLAWS SEEN IN NO-SWIPE CARDS -- Researchers say they have discovered several potential security and privacy holes in a new generation of credit cards whose data is relayed by radio waves without need of a signature or a physical swipe through a machine. [C1.]    GAP STARTS SHOE SITE -- The success of Zappos, the online shoe store, has enticed Gap Inc., which is in a sales slump, to introduce its own shoe site. Last week the company unveiled a new brand, Piperlime, on a Web site that features thousands of footwear styles from 150 brands. Toby C. Lenk, above, president of Gap Direct, the company's Internet division, said that his unit's recent technology upgrade had been paying off. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C9.]    GOOGLE ATTRACTS LAWSUITS -- As Google has grown into the world's most popular search engine, it has become entangled in scores of lawsuits touching on a wide range of legal questions, including copyright violation, trademark infringement and its method of ranking Web sites. [C1.]    A TV SHOW'S QUICK RETREAT -- CBS has canceled its new television show ''Smith,'' even though the first three episodes attracted an average audience of more than 9 million. The move points out how television, like the movie industry, has become a business where there is little room for a modest success. [C1.]    NEW ROLE FOR TONY HAWK -- Rolling Stone is joining forces with two of its advertisers, Activision and Jeep, in a promotional program centered on Mr. Hawk, the skateboarding star. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C10.]    AOL SEEKS EUROPEAN EXPANSION -- AOL attracted 31 million unique visitors to its European Web sites last month while Google sites drew more than 160 million. Jonathan F. Miller, chief executive of AOL, wants to start closing that gap as the company tries to transform itself from a business supported largely by subscriber fees to one financed primarily by advertising. [C4.]    ROSE AND WAL-MART CHIEF -- Just two months after Charlie Rose, left, scored an interview with H. Lee Scott Jr., the camera-shy chief executive of Wal-Mart, Mr. Rose is honoring Mr. Scott at a private dinner party for his work on behalf of the environment. The close timing of interview and the dinner has raised the eyebrows of Mike Getler, the ombudsman at PBS, which distributes Mr. Rose's talk show. ''Don't do this,'' was Mr. Getler's unsolicited advice to Mr. Rose. [C4.]    NORTH KOREA SAYS NO TO WEB -- While some restrictive governments have sought ways to limit the Internet -- through filters, blocks and threats -- North Korea has chosen to stay wholly off the grid. Tom Zeller Jr.: Link by Link. INTERNATIONAL A3-11    Sudan Fighting Threatens Wider African Conflict  A visit to the site of the newest fighting in Sudan revealed a hardening conflict that is increasingly taking place along porous borders among some of the least stable countries in Africa, threatening to ignite a wide conflagration in the heart of the continent.   A1    Sudan's government ordered the chief United Nations envoy out of the country, saying he was an enemy of the country and its armed forces. Secretary General Kofi Annan said he was reviewing the letter from the Khartoum government and had asked the envoy, Jan Pronk, to return to New York for ''consultations.''   A11    18 Killed in Iraqi Violence  A deadly ambush of police recruits north of Baghdad and multiple bombings against shoppers in the capital put a violent stamp on the preparations for the Muslim celebration marking the end of the holy month of Ramadan. The violence left at least 18 Iraqis dead overall, officials said.   A10    A senior State Department official apologized for saying the United States has acted with ''arrogance'' and ''stupidity'' in its campaign in Iraq.   A10    Panama Endorses Canal Plan  Panamanians endorsed a plan to modernize the country's aging canal, won over by government arguments that the $5.25 billion project would generate jobs and keep the canal relevant for future generations. The overhaul, to begin next year, will double the canal's capacity.   A3    Mideast Cease-Fire Crumbles  Tensions between rival Fatah and Hamas loyalists continued to smolder in the form of a deadly shooting, a kidnapping and tire-burning protests as an informal cease-fire disintegrated after only a few days. In Jerusalem, some Israeli cabinet members called for retaking control of Gaza's border with Egypt.   A6    India Rethinks Attack Evidence  Three weeks after the police in India accused Pakistan's intelligence agency of colluding in serial bombings on the commuter train line in Mumbai, M. K. Narayanan, the Indian national security adviser, said in an interview broadcast on television that the evidence was short of ''clinching.''   A8    Clans Clash in Afghanistan  Factional fighting between the followers of rival commanders of two Pashtun clans in the Afghan province of Herat killed 32 fighters and wounded numerous others, said an assistant to Ismail Khan, the former governor of Herat.   A8    Serbian Unity on Constitution  Serbia's leaders, normally riven by deep political rivalries, have shown a surprising degree of unity this month, as ultranationalists and reformers have joined together to support a recently drafted constitution that will be voted on in a referendum on Oct. 27 and 28.   A11    NATIONAL A12-17    G.O.P. Leaders Aiming To Change View of Election  The capital is filled with Republicans convinced they will lose the House and maybe the Senate. So last week, the White House and party leaders convened a ''friends and allies'' teleconference to dispute what Ken Mehlman, chairman of the Republican National Committee, considers flawed conventional wisdom.   A1    A Costly Kansas Town  A breakdown of new Census Bureau data shows that housing costs have risen as a burden in almost every part of the country since 2000. And it is hardly surprising that the coasts, in places like Southern California and Manhattan, figured prominently. But Olathe, Kan., is also at the top of the charts.  A1    Energy Deregulation Aftermath  The enormous profits from the purchase of energy companies were one surprising result of a huge deregulation effort on the part of 21 states a decade ago that overhauled the business of providing electricity, all in the name of stimulating competition and lowering utility bills. But even as some investors have profited, electricity customers have not fared so well.   A1    Senator Considers White House  Senator Barack Obama, the first-term Illinois Democrat who has rapidly emerged as one of the most popular figures in his party, said he was considering running for the White House in 2008, a shift in position that he said had come in response to many Democrats pressing him to join the field.   A12    Fantasy Congress Makes Debut  Fantasy Congress, a Web site created by four students at Claremont McKenna College, made its debut three weeks ago and through word of mouth and blog mentions has attracted almost 600 interested players from the Beltway to Texas.   A12    Bush Promoter Reaches Deal  The conservative commentator Armstrong Williams has reached a settlement with prosecutors regarding payments he received from the Education Department to promote President Bush's agenda. Under the settlement, Mr. Williams admits no wrongdoing but will have to pay $34,000 that prosecutors determined he had been overpaid.  A16    Seniority as Campaign Asset  Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., a Republican, plays up his 26 years in the House on the campaign trail, advising that he has ''a darned good shot'' at leading the powerful Ways and Means Committee.   A14    Town Debates College Drinking  Searchers combing the Mississippi River recently found the body of the eighth college-age man in nine years to disappear from a tavern in La Crosse, Wis., and turn up dead in a river. City officials have debated for years how to keep drunken students safe, but some say there may be no answer for a town with three colleges, three rivers and $3 pitchers of beer.   A12    NEW YORK/REGION B1-7    Clinton Adheres to Script In Second and Final Debate  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton mixed gravitas and familiar talking points in the second and final debate with her Republican opponent, John Spencer. She challenged Bush administration policy on Iraq, Iran and North Korea while carefully defending her own record on abortion rights.  B7    Quicker Citizenship, for Some  Officials of the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services say they have shrunk the average wait for a citizenship decision to five months. But to accomplish their mission, the agency has identified and stopped counting thousands of backlogged cases that they now define as outside the agency's control.  B1    Blessing for Gay Unions  Bishop Andrew D. Smith, the leader of the Episcopal diocese in Connecticut, has authorized priests to give blessings to same-sex unions during religious ceremonies. The move threatens to further alienate the conservative wing of his church and deepen a fissure between progressive and orthodox Episcopalians nationwide.  B1    SPORTSMONDAY D1-10    Detroit Evens Series  Tigers's left hander Kenny Rogers gave up two hits over eight innings as Detroit beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-1, to even the World Series at one game apiece. D1    Engine Trouble Topples Burton  A week after Jeff Burton, left, set himself up as the driver to beat in the annual Nextel Cup playoff, a failed engine assured that all but one racecar beat him in the Subway 500 at Martinsville Speedway.  D5    Baseball Labor Agreement  Commissioner Bud Selig is expected to make a major announcement, as soon as Tuesday or Wednesday, saying that negotiators for the owners and the players have reached agreement on a new five-year labor contract to replace the one that expires Dec. 19.  D7    OBITUARIES B8    Jane Wyatt  The actress best known for co-starring with Robert Young in the television sitcom ''Father Knows Best,'' she was 95.  B8    BUSINESS DAY C1-16    Flaws Seen in New Cards  Researchers say they have discovered several potential security and privacy holes in a new generation of credit cards whose data is relayed by radio waves without need of a signature or a physical swipe through a machine. Lake will give Mr. Skilling a sentence of at least 25 years for his role in heading a conspiracy to defraud Enron investors. If it exceeds that, it would be the longest sentence ever handed down for a white-collar crime. The homestretch of America's campaign season historically puts treacherous distortions of the truth before the voters, none more so this year than a mysterious California letter informing thousands of Latino-Americans that immigrants have no right to vote. "You are advised," begins the Spanish-language letter, dripping with authority, that if "you're an immigrant, voting in a federal election is a crime that can result in incarceration." It now appears that someone in a Republican Congressional campaign conjured a contemporary spin on a classic scare tactic from torchlight politics.

INTERNATIONAL A3-11    Iraqi Court Sentences Hussein to Death  Three and a half years after American troops captured Baghdad and ended the dictatorship of Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi court set up to judge the brutalities of his 24 years in power sentenced him to death by hanging after finding him guilty of crimes against humanity.  A1    The death penalty for Mr. Hussein and two of his co-defendants brought jubilation to Shiite and Kurdish neighborhoods across Iraq, gloom to Sunni ones, and a political blessing for its current, embattled prime minister.   A11    Taiwan's Leader Admits Lies  President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan admitted he submitted false receipts for reimbursement from public funds and lied to prosecutors about how he spent the money, but said he had done so in the interest of national security.   A6    China Sets African Trade Deals  China and a number of African nations agreed on 16 trade and investment deals valued at $1.9 billion, as Beijing extended its efforts to create a broad economic and diplomatic partnership with Africa.   A6    Nicaraguans Vote for Leader  Nicaraguans went to the polls to choose a new president in a five-way contest that primarily focused on one contender: Daniel Ortega, the former Marxist president who fought American-backed contras in a bloody war in the 1980s.   A8    Israel Firm on Gaza Offensive  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel said the military would not halt its offensive in the northern Gaza Strip until Palestinian rocket fire toward Israel was reduced.  A11    Snag for Kosovo Independence  The hopes of ethnic Albanians that Kosovo would be granted independence by the end of this year were placed in doubt as Secretary General Kofi Annan said a decision on the future of the United Nations-administered province could be delayed.   A8    Turk Hints at Freer Speech  Prime Minister Recep Erdogan of Turkey signaled he was prepared to amend a law limiting free speech, a surprise move that was apparently an 11th-hour attempt to prevent a crisis with the European Union over Turkey's troubled membership talks.   A8    NATIONAL A12-19    G.O.P. Finds Issues For Rallying Its Voters  President Bush seized on the sentencing of Saddam Hussein as a ''milestone'' in Iraq, seeking to rally Republican voters with the issue of national security as some polls suggested that his party might be making gains in the final hours of the campaign. The White House said the timing of the announcement, two days before Election Day, had nothing to do with American politics.   A1    Campaigning Coast to Coast  To inspire his troops on the last big day of campaigning for the midterm elections, Representative Mike Fitzpatrick, a Republican in his first term, pulled out a favorite weapon of Republican candidates in the same predicament: Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican whose reputation as a maverick makes him an appealing attraction.   A17    In one of the tightest races in the country, Indiana's Ninth Congressional District, an important economic concern, high gasoline prices, has been somewhat alleviated in the past few weeks as the price at the pump has edged down.   A17    A new poll, which queried 400 likely voters and was published by The Miami Herald, found that 49 percent said they preferred the Democratic challenger, State Senator Ron Klein, to Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr. , who drew the support of 40 percent of respondents.   A17    As volunteers lined up to carry the last paper sacks of leaflets into a web of suburbs to the west of Chicago, Iraq loomed over the tense race for the Congressional seat that is being vacated by Henry J. Hyde, a Republican.   A17    Many Candidates Unopposed  Though the Democrats need only 15 seats to take control of the House, 34 House candidates (30 Democrats and 4 Republicans) have no opponent at all.   A16    Minister Asks for Forgiveness  Thousands of people gathered at the Colorado Springs church whose founder, Ted Haggard, was dismissed for ''sexually immoral conduct.'' Speakers urged the church's members to find a way forward without recrimination or bitterness; a letter from Mr. Haggard was read from the 8,000-seat auditorium's center stage, urging forgivness for the Denver man who broke the story.   A12    NEW YORK/REGION B1-8    Final Political Push Is Felt By Voters in New Jersey  Volunteers bounded from door to door, the airwaves filled with advertisements and carefully chosen political celebrities popped up across New Jersey as the state became a battlefield for both parties in the final days of the midterm campaign. With Democrats appearing within reach of gaining the six seats they need to take control of the United States Senate, New Jersey has become a focus of national attention. B1    State Republicans Cry Foul  Anticipating historic political losses in New York on Election Day, state Republican leaders are lashing out at the national party in Washington, saying it has exploited New York donors and missed opportunities against a prime target, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. They say that, despite pleas for help, they have been ignored in Washington.  B1    Cigarette Trade in Jeopardy  The tax-free sale of steeply discounted cigarettes by the Shinnecock Indian Outpost in Southampton is what keeps the tribe alive. But now the cigarette trade is being threatened by both a federal lawsuit and an expected push by the New York State government, which estimates it loses $576 million a year in the sale of untaxed cigarettes.  B1    Brooklyn Development Faulted  Even in Greenpoint-Williamsburg, an area familiar with growth and gentrification, the sweeping changes wrought by the city's rezoning have left many residents feeling dizzied, and there is a sense that the government has not moved fast enough to keep pace with developers.  B1    Neediest Cases  B6    ARTS E1-10    Students Build in Mississippi  Architects in training at Parsons the New School for Design volunteered for six weeks of rugged work in hurricane-ravaged Mississippi, conceiving and building a combination information center and laundromat. E1    World War II Photos Unearthed  Close to 800 images by the photographer Dorothea Lange depicting the World War II-era internment of Japanese and Japanese-American citizens have been unearthed in the National Archives, where they had lain neglected for a half-century after being impounded by the government.  E1    BUSINESS DAY C1-10    Medicare and Democrats  Democrats, who have long charged that the drug industry is profiteering at taxpayers' expense, say they want to introduce legislation to revoke the law that bars Medicare from negotiating prices directly with drug makers like Pfizer for the medicines it buys.   C1    Studios Seek Concessions  Movie and television studios, facing escalating budgets, rampant piracy and the uncertain future of new media, are demanding concessions from actors, directors and writers.   C1    Google Expands Advertising  Google will start taking bids for the sale of advertisements that will appear in the print editions of 50 major newspapers, in a three-month test to start later this month. TRYING TO REGULATE AN ARMY -- For years, companies including Avon Products, Herbalife and Amway have prospered by building armies of part-time sales representatives promoting insurance plans and anti-aging creams. Those representatives, in turn, are encouraged to recruit others and are promised that they will receive a portion of new enlistees' profits. The companies profit, at least in part, by collecting increased revenue and fees paid by new sales representatives. In April, citing hundreds of fraud investigations, the Federal Trade Commission proposed new rules for multilevel marketing companies and related businesses. [Page C1.]    SHORTCUT TO FASHION -- For fashionistas in lower tax brackets, reproducing the latest hip look from Lindsay Lohan or Paris Hilton can mean endless clicking through online retail sites and hit-or-miss searches on Google or shopping engines like Shopping.com. Now a new search site, Like.com, offers a shortcut for the budget-minded. The site and its chief executive, Munjal Shah, left, rely on artificial-intelligence technology to search images on the Web, and serve up goods for sale that visually match items on a shopper's wish list. E-Commerce Report, Bob Tedeschi. [C4.]    LIFE IN THE STUDIO -- In an era when producers, directors and popular actors are required to toe a stricter line, even Jerry Bruckheimer, the producer, is feeling the squeeze. His contribution to Disney cannot be underestimated. He has produced 17 films for the studio since 1991. They have brought in $5 billion. As part of a shift under Robert A. Iger, the new Disney chief executive, the studio pledged to make fewer films and focus on family-friendly movies that are marketable across all the company's businesses. That means Mr. Bruckheimer is now in the onscreen amusement park business. [C1.]    MOVING ON AFTER XBOX -- The hoopla was still swelling around November's debut of the Xbox 360, when some on its development team began conceiving a new product. Tomorrow, after committing hundreds of millions of dollars, Microsoft is scheduled to release the result of that research: the Zune. At a glance, it looks like yet another aspiring iPod rival. But the Zune can do something that no other player can claim: it can locate other Zune players and wirelessly exchange content with a few touches of a big shiny button. [C1.]    MUSIC FILLS THE AIR -- The upscale department store Nordstrom, which has taken a chance on up-and-coming designers, is now betting on a different set of rising stars: musicians. Beginning this holiday season, the retailer will develop and sell a collection of CDs that, over time, is expected to rival the one carried by Starbucks, its corporate neighbor in Seattle. [C11.]    TAKING A NEW PATH -- Two big advertisers known for following traditional ways of marketing products are expanding their efforts to become a little less conventional. Both, coincidentally, share the same creative and media agencies, which are also trying to demonstrate their eagerness to explore the brave world of new media. The advertisers are the General Electric Company and the Pepsi-Cola North America unit of PepsiCo. The agencies are both part of the Omnicom Group: BBDO Worldwide in New York for the creative parts of the campaigns and OMD for the media elements. Everyone on Madison Avenue ''is looking to push the envelope, find what is going to be the next big thing,'' said Jennifer Gordineer, group director for national investment on the PepsiCo account at OMD. Advertising, Stuart Elliott. [C8.]    GETTING A SECOND CHANCE -- Even adults, it seems, are getting a little sick of their childhoods, long after everyone else has. So TV Land, the network best-known for reruns of ''The Andy Griffith Show,'' is unveiling programming to appeal to what the network sees as one of the next obsessions for baby boomers: optimism about having second careers and changing lifestyles. Having recently produced reality shows with Farrah Fawcett and Mr. T, the network, which is owned by Viacom, is now turning its cameras on George Foreman, the former heavyweight boxing champion-turned-grill purveyor. [C10.]    FINANCING FOR ETHANOL -- The Mascoma Corporation, a company that is trying to produce ethanol from nontraditional sources, has received $30 million from a group of prominent venture capital investors. The investment, which is led by General Catalyst Partners, and includes Khosla Ventures, Flagship Ventures, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers and others, is the latest in a string of venture capital financings of alternative energy companies. Khosla and Flagship invested $9 million in Mascoma earlier this year. [C4.]

Holocene Impact Working Group, two-year-old project made up of international research scientists, seeks to investigate theory that space objects hit earth and cause catastrophic events much more frequently and more recently than originally thought; studies chevron formations on land to help point way to undersea craters; believes that impacts could happen as often as every thousand years; Dr Dallas Abbott, Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, Palisades, NY, research scientist, uses satellite technology to find ocean craters; recently discovered Burckle crater is believed to have generated chevron-shaped hills on Madagascar; maps; photos; graphs (M)

The growing number of hedge-fund investments in technology startups means that ‚Äúthe old way of doing things is being disrupted,‚Äù the Red Herring declares. While hedge funds often help companies as they approach their initial public offerings, their presence can sometimes create conflict. The main problem, according to the Herring, is that hedge funds and venture capitalists have very different expectations for returns. While a venture capitalist might be looking for a return of 60 percent or more from a given start-up, a hedge fund, being more diversified, might be satisfied with 20 percent.

Consortium of seven newspaper chains representing 176 daily papers across the country will enter partnership with Yahoo to share content, advertising and technology; first phase of deal entails posting of newspapers' employment classified ads on Yahoo's classified jobs site, HotJobs, and newspapers' use of HotJobs technology to run their own online career ads; long-term goal of alliance is to be able to have content of these newspapers tagged and optimized for searching and indexing by Yahoo; that would allow local news--one of pillars of newspaper business--to become part of large information network that would increase usefulness for readers and value to advertisers; consortium members are MediaNews Group, Hearst, Belo, E W Scripps, Journal Register Co, Lee Enterprises and Cox Enterprises; photos (M)

NEW YORK ‚Äî A consortium of seven newspaper chains representing 176 daily newspapers across the United States is planning a broad partnership with Yahoo to share content, advertising and technology online in an attempt to increase traffic and revenue at both the No. 1 Internet portal and the newspapers' own Web sites.
The alliance is a sign that wary newspapers are increasingly willing to shake hands with the technology companies they once saw as a threat.

The Universal Music Group, the world‚Äôs largest music company, filed a copyright infringement lawsuit yesterday against MySpace, the popular social networking Web site, for allowing users to upload and download songs and music videos. The suit, which also names MySpace‚Äôs corporate parent, the News Corporation, comes as the recording industry contends with how to exploit its copyrighted material online.

Magazines love lists, and Fortune loves them more than most. For its latest roster of the most powerful people in business, however, Fortune has changed its approach. Whereas it had previously ranked its power players from No. 1 to No. 25, the magazine‚Äôs latest issue features 25 moodily lit black-and-white photos of the business elite, in no apparent order, in a feature called ‚ÄúPortraits of Power.‚Äù Part of the reason for eliminating the rankings was, according to the article, the ‚Äúever-shifting value of influence in the business world.‚Äù (We would imagine it also helps avoid bruised egos among moguls.)

Everyone seems to have a theory about why Yahoo! is struggling. Google, its rival and a darling of the investment world, is often cited as a major cause of the Web portal‚Äôs woes. Yahoo senior vice president Brad Garlinghouse recently compared his company‚Äôs predicament to a popular condiment in a four-page internal memo dubbed ‚ÄúThe Peanut Butter Manifesto.‚Äù Whatever the cause, The New York Times wrote Monday that there is an emerging consensus about one thing: If Yahoo remains an underachiever, it could be a candidate for takeover.
Forget blue states and red states. The more important divide is between the blue city and the red country.

Major Internet sites are showing strong and growing interest in advertising business, and traditional ad firms are starting to get concerned; Google has been leading way, building on its online ad strength by striking deals to sell advertising in traditional media like newspapers and radio; eBay is developing ad-buying system for TV spots for group of large advertisers like Wal-Mart; Yahoo announces deal with 176 newspapers that does not include offline ad sales, although newspaper executives do not rule that out; ad executives say it is hard to know where Google and other Internet giants will stop; traditional media companies are linking up with online giants that have been stealing their customers and advertisers; traditional companies--like newspapers, magazines, and television and radio networks--are hoping they can reverse their fortunes and share in some of Internet success; stock analysts say offline ad market provides kind of growth opportunity that Internet companies like Google are looking for; Google plans to sell ad spots on radio beginning next month through online auction system that it uses to sell Internet ads; ad sales in traditional media totaled nearly $150 billion last year; Internet ad sales will be about $16 billion this year; WPP Group chief executive Martin Sorrell sees Google as both friend and enemy; Google vice president Tim Armstrong says Google hopes to one day provide place where advertisers can buy ads in all types of media; adds Google's vision does not involve cutting agencies' media buyers out of system; photos (L)

ENVY IN SILICON VALLEY -- Envy may be a sin in some books, but it is a powerful driving force in Silicon Valley. And now that Google's purchase of YouTube for $1.65 billion has amplified talk of a second dot-com boom, many high-tech entrepreneurs -- like Reid Hoffman, above, an early executive of PayPal who profited when eBay bought the company in 2002 but recently watched his former PayPal colleagues make out even better on the sale of YouTube -- are examining their lives as measured against upstarts who have made it bigger. [Page A1.]    SIMPSON BOOK CANCELED -- Bowing to intense pressure both outside and inside the company, the News Corporation canceled its plans to publish a book and broadcast an interview with O. J. Simpson in which he was to give a hypothetical account of how he might have murdered his ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ronald Goldman. [A1.]    ELBOWING IN ON TRADITIONAL ADS -- Major Internet sites like Google, eBay and Yahoo are showing a strong and growing interest in the advertising business, and traditional ad firms are starting to get worried. Paulson Jr. said that excessive regulation and burdensome litigation were prompting companies to choose to list their stock on foreign exchanges over American ones. [C1.]    FLAWS SEEN IN UTILITIES MARKET -- A growing chorus of large industrial power users, municipal utilities and consumer groups says there is a reason the price of electricity has not fallen since the federal government opened the heavily regulated utility industry to competition a decade ago. The new markets, they argue, do not work right. [C1.]    CHEAP DEBT FUELS DEALS -- Not so long ago, companies that borrowed lots of money were considered risky. Those with cash on hand and few debts might be dull stocks, but they were at least safe bets for bondholders. That view is being turned on its head. Market Place. [C1.]    JANITORS END STRIKE -- Ending a monthlong strike, the union representing 5,300 janitors in Houston and the city's major cleaning companies announced a tentative contract that raises their wages by nearly 50 percent over two years and provides health coverage. [A18.]    REDSTONE FAMILY LAWSUIT -- Michael Redstone is suing his uncle, Viacom's chairman, Sumner M. Redstone, and his own father, Edward Redstone, saying they cheated him and his late sister Ruth Ann out of their rightful interests in the family company. [C3.]    GIANT REIT ACCEPTS BUYOUT OFFER --Equity Office Properties, the nation's largest office landlord, accepted a $36 billion offer from the Blackstone Group. It would be the costliest buyout in history. [C3.]    TARGET EXPANDS $4 DRUGS -- The Target Corporation expanded its $4 generic drug program to all of its pharmacies, moving beyond states where it was matching a plan offered by its rival, Wal-Mart Stores. [C10.]    RUSSIAN BID FOR STEEL MILLS -- The Russian billionaire Roman A. Abramovich offered $2.3 billion for an Oregon steel mill in what would be the largest Russian investment to date in the United States. [C11.]    LONDON EXCHANGE REJECTS OFFER -- The London Stock Exchange, the largest in Europe, rejected a $5 billion cash offer from the Nasdaq Stock Market and said it would not meet with Nasdaq executives. Nasdaq officials said that while they still hoped to reach a friendly deal, they planned to go ahead with their offer. [C1.]    POST LOSES REPORTERS TO WEB -- The Washington Post, which has long prided itself on the depth and breadth of its coverage of national politics, lost two of its top political reporters to a fledgling Internet-focused news organization, albeit one with deep pockets. SAN FRANCISCO ‚Äî Almost anywhere else, Reid Hoffman would be considered a major success. As an early executive of PayPal, he was in the money when the company was sold to eBay in 2002 for $1.5 billion.

GOOGLE, STILL FEELING LUCKY -- Google's shares closed up $14.60 at $509.65, rising past the $500 mark for the first time, not bad for a company that was forced to reduce its initial share price to $85 barely two years ago because of lackluster demand. And an analyst who once recommended selling at $137 is among those predicting that it will rise to $600 within a year. [Page C1.]    A LINE IN THE SAND -- Rupert Murdoch has pushed the boundaries throughout his career, usually without contrition. But the media billionaire's decision to cancel a TV and book project featuring O. J. Simpson by subsidiaries of the News Corporation was a rare demonstration that even Mr. Murdoch has his limits. [C1.]    RIGHTS TO SIMPSON BOOK SOUGHT -- Seeking to prevent a canceled book and television interview with O. J. Simpson from ever becoming public, the family of Ronald L. Goldman, who was murdered along with Nicole Brown Simpson in 1994, has asked the News Corporation to turn over the rights to the material. [C5.]    INVESTORS SHOW FAITH IN DELL -- Dell reported another quarter of slow revenue growth and falling profits, compared to year-earlier results. But investors looked at the marked improvement from the previous quarter as a sign of a turnaround and pushed the company's stock up in after-hours trading. [C1.]    SENATOR AT THE CROSSROADS -- As Senator Christopher Dodd prepares to take over the leadership of the Senate Banking Committee while also considering a run for the presidency, lobbyists and lawmakers are all asking the same question. Will he be a populist champion for the middle class or will he advance the causes of corporate patrons? [C1.]    ASIAN GIANTS SEEK CLOSER TIES -- India and China established a 10-point strategy to strengthen economic relations as President Hu Jintao of China, left, started a four-day visit to India. As he and Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India came face to face, there was evidence that they were trying to define the Asian version of globalization. [C2.]    SHORT-LIVED SOFTWARE CEASE-FIRE -- Less than three weeks after they reached an accord hailed as proof that open source and proprietary software companies could work together, Novell and Microsoft executives are bickering in public. [C4.]    POTATO TODAY, GONE TOMORROW -- The United States Potato Board is joining the ranks of marketers using a technique known as pop-up retailing, opening a temporary store that consumers can visit for a short time. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C4.]    LENS CLEANER RECALLED -- Advanced Medical Optics has recalled 2.9 million bottles of Complete MoisturePlus contact lens solution after harmful bacteria were found in some units sold in Japan. The company's shares fell 8.9 percent, and the company issued lowered forecasts for sales and earnings through 2007. The voluntary recall is a precaution against eye infections caused by water-borne bacteria that infiltrated a plant in China; no problems have been reported in the United States. [C6.]    COMCAST AND DISNEY IN DEAL -- The Comcast Corporation and the Walt Disney Company have signed a multibillion-dollar distribution deal that allows the cable operator to distribute Disney content through its video-on-demand service. [C10.]    G.M. SCUTTLES SATURN MINIVAN -- General Motors confirmed that it had decided not to build a Saturn minivan that was tentatively planned for production at its Spring Hill, Tenn., plant, but the company said that it would find a new vehicle for workers there to build. Union leaders said they feared the plant, where the first Saturn was built, would close. [C4.]    PENTAGON SEEKS SUPERCOMPUTER -- The Pentagon awarded almost $500 million in contracts to I.B.M. and Cray Inc. to design a supercomputer several times as fast as today's most powerful systems. [C8.]    AVIATION COMPANY RISES IN DEBUT -- Shares of Spirit AeroSystems Holdings, a unit of Onex, the Canadian leveraged buyout company, rose 12 percent in their first day of trading in New York yesterday. Onex formed Spirit in June 2005 after acquiring Boeing's aircraft component factories in Wichita, Kan., and Tulsa and McAlester, Okla. Spirit stock opened at $26 and ended the day's trading at $29 a share. [C8]    STOCKS RISE WITH OIL PRICES -- Stocks resumed their November advance yesterday after an increase in oil prices lifted the Exxon Mobil Corporation, the world's biggest energy company, and shares of Google surpassed $500 for the first time. THE $100 LAPTOP A nonprofit project to build a $100 laptop for children in the developing world is winning over many skeptics. Five countries have made tentative commitments to put the computers into the hands of millions of students, with production in Taiwan expected to begin by mid-2007. [Page A1.]    HARD TIMES FOR WAL-MART Wal-Mart is expected to announce next week that sales for November fell for the first time in a decade, leading some industry experts to wonder whether the retailer is changing too fast, acting more like a start-up than a 44-year-old company with 6,000 stores, 1.3 million employees and sales of $312 billion. [A1.]    GAUGING THE IMPACT OF $4 DRUGS Wal-Mart says that its $4 generic drug program is attracting new customers to its stores and starting the nation on a road that will squeeze billions of dollars from prescription drug spending. But two months into the program, it is unclear whether Wal-Mart is meeting its stated goal of making a profit on those drugs. [C1.]    BUYOUTS COSTLY FOR FORD The Ford Motor Company expects to burn through $17 billion -- nearly half of its cash reserves -- by 2009, mostly in the next year as 40 percent of its hourly workers voluntarily leave their jobs. [C1.]    WORRIES OVER KIDNEY DRUGS An expert panel of doctors for the National Kidney Foundation plans to assess whether hundreds of thousands of patients with kidney disease are being dangerously overtreated with drugs for anemia. [C1.]    TROUBLE WITH PATROL BOATS After spending $100 million to renovate eight of its workhorse cutters, the Coast Guard will announce that it is suspending the use of the Florida-based patrol boats because of chronic hull cracking and engine problems. [A22.]    CARBON DIOXIDE ON TRIAL A Supreme Court argument on the Bush administration's refusal to regulate carbon dioxide in automobile emissions offered three intertwined plot lines to the audience that had come to watch the court's first encounter with the issue of global climate change. [A23.]    A NEW CLASS SYSTEM India, once divided chiefly by caste, is creating a different divide by skills. Those with marketable skills are sought for service call centers and software houses; those without are ensnared in drudgery. Search engine Ask.com is introducing AskCity, service that integrates maps with information about local businesses, restaurants, concerts and movie listings and reviews; so-called local searches already account for 10 percent of all Internet queries and are expected to grow faster than other searches; they are also seen as way to tap into tens of billions in spending by small businesses, which have yet to switch much of their advertising dollars to Internet; early reviews of service by analysts are positive; Ask.com Jim Lanzone and Barry Diller, who acquired Ask site in March 2005, comment on Ask's future; map; photos (L)

Yahoo and Reuters, hoping to turn millions of people with digital cameras and camera phones into photojournalists, are introducing new effort to showcase photographs and video of news events submitted by public; photos and videos submitted beginning Dec 5 will be placed throughout Reuters.com and Yahoo News; Reuters says it will also start to distribute some of submissions next year to thousands of print, online and broadcast media outlets that subscribe to its news service; says it hopes to develop service devoted entirely to user-submitted photographs and video; project is among most ambitious efforts in what has become known as citizen journalism, attempts by bloggers, start-up local news sites and by global news organizations to see if readers can also become reporters; users will be able to upload photos and videos to section of Yahoo called You Witness News; photos (L)

Online advertising is racing ahead in Britain, growing at about 40 percent annual rate, and is expected to account for as much as 14 percent of overall ad spending this year; figure is highest level in world, and more than double percentage in US; much of advertising in Britain is national, while there are strong local and regional ad markets in America; some believe that online advertising in Britain provides somewhat of roadmap for where online ads in US and elsewhere may be heading; British marketers seem to have bought into oft-touted benefits of Internet advertising: that is is easy to track, enormously effective and relative bargain; graph; photos (L)

Jellyfish.com, TheFind.com and MyTriggers.com, among others, are taking direct aim at Shopzilla and Shopping.com, most popular sites for finding goods online; three new sites are taking advantage of what some executives say is increasing discomfort with pay-per-click model, which has grown more expensive as marketers bid more aggressively for premium space alongside search results; on these new sites, advertisers typically pay only when someone actually buys something or when users view ad; MyTriggers chief executive Glenn S Meyers says his cost-per-action advertising approach also yields better user experience, since shoppers are shown products much more relevant to them, not simply items from highest-paying advertisers; photo (M)

A CHALLENGE TO PAY-PER-CLICK -- Shopping.com, Shopzilla.com and PriceGrabber.com made attractive acquisitions last year, partly because all were following Google's pay-per-click advertising model. The sites offer search boxes and product directories, typically presenting items so that when users click on a link, they are in essence clicking on a merchant's ad. But new sites, like Jellyfish, TheFind and MyTriggers, are taking advantage of an increasing discomfort with the pay-per-click model. On these new sites, advertisers typically pay only when someone buys something or when users view an ad. E-Commerce Report, Bob Tedeschi. [C6.]    AN OUTLET FOR PHOTOS -- Hoping to turn the millions of people with digital cameras and camera phones into photojournalists, Yahoo and Reuters are introducing an effort to showcase photographs and video of news events submitted by the public. Starting tomorrow, the photos and videos submitted will be placed throughout Reuters.com and Yahoo News. Reuters said that it would start to distribute some submissions to media outlets that subscribe to its news service. [C6.]    ARTICLE BLOCKED IN RUSSIA -- In a sign of the growing reach of Russia's business elite, a billionaire, Yelena Baturina, tried -- and for a time succeeded -- in blocking an article in the Russian edition of Forbes magazine that featured her on its cover. The episode again raised questions about intimidation of the press. The December edition appeared on newsstands a day late and after the editor in chief, Maksim Kashulinsky, above, resigned in protest. [C4.]    ASK GOES LOCAL -- Like every other major search company, Ask would like to narrow Google's lead, and it has made some progress. In the last four months, Ask has regained market share that it lost last year. And on Monday, Ask.com is introducing AskCity, a service that integrates maps with information about local businesses, restaurants, concerts and movies. [C1.]    IN BRITAIN, THE ONLINE FUTURE -- Online advertising in Britain offers a glimpse of the future for the ad world, growing at a roughly 40 percent annual rate. It is expected to account for as much as 14 percent of overall ad spending this year in Britain, the highest level in the world, and more than double the percentage in America. Advertising. [C1.]    WAL-MART TRIES TO RAISE MORALE -- Faced with demonstrations of discontent by its employees, Wal-Mart Stores has developed a program to show that it appreciates its 1.3 million workers in the United States and to encourage them to air their grievances. As part of the effort, Wal-Mart managers will hold monthly meetings with rank-and-file workers and extend a 10 percent discount on a single product during the holidays to all its employees. [C1.]    WA LL STREET JOURNAL REDESIGN -- Executives of The Wall Street Journal will unveil today the prototype for its redesign, part of a $100 million overhaul beginning on Jan. 2 that will shrink the physical size of the paper. This will save money but also reduce the space devoted to news by 10 percent. Many of the changes are intended to help the time-pressed reader move through the paper faster. [C4.]    PRIME-TIME CHANGES AT CNN -- While the daytime ratings at Headline News have grown a modest 10 percent among viewers coveted by advertisers, those from ages 25 to 54, the ratings are up 48 percent at Headline Prime, the prime-time program that summarizes the news, into brash, personality-driven talk-TV. But with the improved ratings come a question: how can CNN compete with the more opinionated prime-time competition while preserving its reputation as an objective news gatherer? [C1.]    FOCUS ON TELECOM GROUP -- This week, the International Telecommunication Union, a United Nations agency representing 191 countries and 650 companies, puts on the telecommunications industry's biggest gathering, called ITU Telecom World. But some of the conference's attention will be focused on the role of the ITU itself. Should it concern itself with Internet governance, or should it focus on more basic issues, like access to telecommunications in developing countries? [C12.]    CITGO PAYS FOR ADS -- Citizens Energy Corporation, the nonprofit heating assistance program, supplies low-income households with oil provided by Citgo, the state-owned Venezuelan oil company. Now for the first time Citgo is also funding Citizens' television commercials, left. The commercials, which advertise ''heating oil at 40 percent off from our friends in Venezuela at Citgo,'' began airing on Nov. 17 in local television markets for the 16 states reached by Citizens Energy. Citgo supplied Citizens with oil last year, but this year is the first time that Citgo will be paying for the Citizens commercials. [C8.]    A SALE, BUT NOT A TITLE -- When HarperCollins announced the impending release of ''If I Did It,'' O. J. Simpson's book about his ex-wife's murder, the title, author and subject came as a surprise to almost everyone -- including the booksellers who had already ordered the book. Mr. Simpson's book, which was canceled, was sold ''blind'' to bookstores a few weeks before its release, a phenomena that is increasingly common in the publishing industry. [C8.]    VIDEO GAMES ON TV -- Competitive video gaming is going to get shot at mainstream network treatment when an hourlong special about the World Series of Video Games appears as part of the CBS Sports Spectacular lineup on Dec. 30. [C8.]

Yahoo is restructuring its operations and shuffling its management ranks amid growing criticism in and outside company that it has become too bureaucratic to compete effectively against rivals; moves include departure of chief operating officer Daniel L Rosensweig and resignation of Lloyd Braun, who has run media group; Yahoo will reorganize itself into three operating units, including one focused on its audience and one on its advertisers and publishers; third unit, focused on technology, will develop products serving entire organization; chairman-chief executive Terry S Semel comments; reorganization appears to signal ascendancy of chief financial official officer Susan L Decker, who is seen as possible candidate to succeed Semel; chief financial officer Farzad Nazem will head new technology group, and Yahoo says it will run external search for executive to lead its audience group, as well as for new chief financial officer; senior vice president Jeff Weiner will assume added responsibilities, including social media, communications and Yahoo's media group; photos (M)

Subscriptions For a Browser    Q. How do I use R.S.S. feeds with Internet Explorer 7?    A. R.S.S., which stands for Really Simple Syndication (or Rich Site Summary, as some prefer), is a format used by Web sites to distribute updates, news, headlines and other information to those who ''subscribe'' to the site's ''feed.'' Web pages with feeds available often display an orange ''R.S.S.'' or ''XML'' icon. (XML stands for Extensible Markup Language, a standard for creating and coding some forms of Web content.)     Internet Explorer, Mozilla Firefox and the latest version of Apple's Safari all provide the ability to subscribe to R.S.S. feeds and read updates right in a browser. There are also stand-alone programs available to collect all the fresh content from your favorite Web sites, but many people prefer just using a browser.

Considering A Media Center PC    Q. I am thinking about buying a new computer in the next month, before I am forced to buy Windows Vista. I see lots of machines with ''Windows XP Media Center Edition 2005.'' What is the difference between this and good old XP?    A. Windows XP Media Center Edition 2005 is a version of Windows XP that is geared more for home-entertainment purposes -- like playing or displaying music, photos and video -- than for just typical computing chores like spreadsheets and word processing. Since it can run programs written for Windows XP, a Media Center PC can also do spreadsheets and word processing, and it can connect to the Internet for Web surfing and e-mail.

Robert Nardelli, the former chief executive of The Home Depot, will receive $210 million in severance compensation, including $20 million in cash, as he departs the U.S. home-improvement chain. Nardelli, who earned $64 million over six years while at the helm of the company, was long the target of shareholders, who were unhappy with the company's declining share price and Nardelli's autocratic style. But Nardelli, who resigned Wednesday, is but the latest U.S. corporate chief to receive a lucrative golden handshake. Henry McKinnell, of Pfizer, took $213 million with him, and Philip Purcell of Morgan Stanley received $113 million. If there is any good news in this case, it is that Home Depot's shareholders were finally heard. They had been smoldering for years over Nardelli's dismissal of their concerns, which began coalescing in 2004 when the company changed the way it calculated long-term incentive pay for executives without telling investors. It came to a head in March, when the Corporate Library named Home Depot's board as one of the 11 worst executive pay offenders, and it blew over in May, when Nardelli decided to run the company's annual meeting alone, without his directors, and limit questions from shareholders. Investors believe Nardelli's departure will lead to changes within the company, and say that some measures have already been undertaken. But is it realistic to think that other companies will get the message, as some observers hope? Why didn't they get the message ‚Äî that chief executives should pay attention to shareholder wealth, not just their own ‚Äî when Purcell, McKinnell or Tom Freston, of Viacom, were shown the door? Hopefully, this time it gets across.

To the Editor: If you lack time for the atomic tourism described in ‚ÄúStrange Love‚Äù (Jan. 5), you can use Google to see satellite photos of decommissioned B-52s at the Boneyard at Davis-Monthan Air Force Base in Tucson. Like Roman ruins, the once formidable planes are a shell of their former selves, their sawed-off fuselages lying sadly in the dust. What used to be terrifying has somehow become poignant, as if a great epoch had ended. I suppose we can find cathartic relief in the mummification of a Titan II missile, but this may be cold comfort. The United States has spent more than $5 trillion on nuclear weapons since 1940, and judging from the current administration‚Äôs Nuclear Posture Review, which was made public in 2002 and calls for a complete revitalization of the country‚Äôs nuclear infrastructure, this spending is far from done. Don‚Äôt be fooled by moth balls. Old nukes are like old rock stars ¬ó they never go away. Jeff Porter.

International premium travel ¬ó that is, first-class and business-class flying ¬ó grew 4.3 percent last year compared with 2005, according to the International Air Transport Association. Premium travel on the trans-Atlantic routes, which represent 16.1 percent of international premium traffic (the biggest proportion when travel within Europe is not counted) rose 7.8 percent in December compared with December 2005, and rose an overall 3.5 percent for the year. Premium traffic on Europe to Asia routes and all routes to the Middle East continued to grow in double digits, said the group, which represents 250 world airlines. I have no memory of the 1960‚Äôs and the ‚Äô70‚Äôs. These tumultuous years bear significant meaning to generations that went before me; yet, the decade lives on with its oldies classics, lunar missions, Vietnamization, and civil rights struggle. One way or another, everyone is captured through the Austin Powers throwbacks, English discussions of The Kind of Light that Shines on Texas, or history readings of two important, yet short-lived presidencies. Back then,the new millennium was anything left to the imagination of those who studied hard and led America to success in recent years. Nowadays, the sixties are more or less the imagination of us college students. If there was ever an adage to come true, it was that history tends to repeat itself.

Growing up, we were bombarded with images of college life and the importance of higher education. By eighteen, we developed expectations and set standards for ourselves far beyond the expectations and standards that our parents faced upon entering adulthood. The modern application process alone forced us to thoroughly assess ourselves and our long-term goals. As if this wasn‚Äôt enough, we evaluated our own strengths, weaknesses, and dreams, in light of those of our peers, and perhaps even manipulated them, so that we might have a chance, just a chance, at being considered for admission to a competitive university. Most of us were fortunate enough to have had the emotional and financial support of our parents to brace us through the process; however, the average parent is incapable of pulling enough strings to secure a successful future for his or her child. College goers of today must accept a reality that is unfamiliar to our parents: Brains and determination, alone, cannot guarantee success. However, also unlike our parents, we do not take no for an answer.

College today is vastly different than it was in the 1960‚Äôs and because of that mainstream America is just not all that interested in campuses. That‚Äôs the point Rick Perlstein hopes to prove in his New York Times piece ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the Matter with College?‚Äù It‚Äôs a point that isn‚Äôt really all that revolutionary, lest of all from someone nostalgically recalling their own college days. Sure, readers are shown that students today are more career-obsessed than their parents but what really matter is why students have changed and how that change might actually be beneficial to a knowledge society.
Logging Onto College

There may be some truth to what Rick Perlstein describes as the disappearance of the classic college experience. To the baby boomer generation, college was an opportunity to open a door to new worlds of knowledge, to do research in fields previously untouched, and to sound really smart saying things no high school kid could understand. Intelligent and intellectually rebellious was cool.

Before I begin, I have the intense need to clarify ‚Äúcollege experience‚Äù, for it is a poor synonym for what is at stake. Stripped to its bare bones, it can be broken down into something that civilizations through the ages can recognize and identify with: knowledge, power and freedom. Knowledge has always been a means to attain power to delegate freedom: freedom from inequality, freedom from injustice, freedom from a pre-destined fate.
Nonscientifically gathered top three answers to the question ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs it going?‚Äù or ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôd you do today?‚Äù at Stanford:

We are there on campus, somewhere. Look hard enough and you will find us. You know us well. There we are ‚Äî walking to class, cell phone in hand, iPod in pocket, conversation in one ear, music in the other. The conversation ends. The phone goes away. And the other headphone takes its place.

The other Monday I was at my friend Scott‚Äôs house. His parents had left for the night, so he threw a party in his basement. Unfortunately, a number of high schoolers had shown up. I went upstairs to get some air and sat down at his kitchen table with a glass of water. With the party rumbling below my feet, I looked over a to-do list that his mom had left for him. I pictured my friend playing with the dogs, taking the garbage out. Scott‚Äôs a tall and funny looking fellow, who does about a hundred pushups every day. He is determined to have a good time in about any place he goes.

In What‚Äôs the Matter with College? Rick Perlstien states that the famed college experience as we know it is extinct. He implies that college campuses are wastelands devoid of creative thought and original thinking. They exist just out of legacy and serve as a stepping stone from high school into the job market. This statement is ill informed. Students and their respective universities need not reevaluate their current standing. The learning experience is still there, but students have to go about finding it in a different way. In the advent of modern technology, most young individuals know much more about themselves then their parents or grandparents did at the same age. Going about finding the right place to help you further your life goals is harder than it once was, but easier too.
Moon or Mars, or both? Economic incentives or political? And who will lead the way?

As much as I enjoy watching ‚ÄúTop Chef‚Äù and effortlessly rattling off choice entries in the foodie vernacular ‚Äì ceviche, amuse bouche, molecular gastronomy ‚Äì I‚Äôm not what you would call an adventurous eater. I convulse at the mere scent of banana and nothing embodies hell on earth for me quite like the texture of rice pudding. For better or worse, I was raised in a home where chicken was the norm and exotic dishes were discreetly fed to the dog as quickly as they were placed on the table. (I‚Äôm remembering one instance in particular involving a rice-and-beef-stuffed pumpkin so vile even Sparky wouldn‚Äôt eat it.) As far as I can tell, I am the typical, boring American eater; I like cheesy, crispy, fatty, salty or sweet food made with ingredients I can pronounce. I crave preservatives and chemically enhanced juices; I crave red-white-and-blue-dyed snack cakes filled with liquefied marshmallow substitute. High fructose corn syrup figuratively ‚Äì and probably literally ‚Äì courses through my veins. So you can imagine my growing distress at America‚Äôs growing palette.

Then the iPod and iTunes changed that; for all but the fanatics, they took the art out of playing music in the car or at home. Over the next couple of years, two very big countries, America and China, will give birth to something very important. They're each going to give birth to close to $1 trillion worth of economic stimulus - in the form of tax cuts, infrastructure, highways, mass transit and new energy systems. But a lot is riding on these two babies. If China and America each give birth to a pig - a big, energy-devouring, climate-spoiling stimulus hog - our kids are done for. Michael Sanderson is worried. Dr. Sanderson, a biologist at the University of Arizona, is part of an effort to figure out how all the estimated 500,000 species of plants are related to one another. For years now the researchers have sequenced DNA from thousands of species from jungles, tundras and museum drawers. They have used supercomputers to crunch the genetic data and have gleaned clues to how today's diversity of baobobs, dandelions, mosses and other plants evolved over the past 450 million years.
